LOAN, EQUITY INVESTMENT, AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower (Loan)  Republic of Indonesia 
(Equity)  Indonesian Infrastructure Financing Facility Company (a limited 
liability company to be established under the laws and regulations 
of Indonesia) 
   
Investment and Loan  To invest the equivalent in rupiah of up to $40 million into the 
Proposal  equity capital of the Indonesian Infrastructure Financing Facility 
Company (IIFF) and to provide a loan of up to $100 million to 
Indonesia for relending to PT Sarana Multi Infrastruktur (PTSMI), 
a  fully  government-owned  holding  company,  which  in  turn  will 
relend  the  loan  of  $100  million  in  its  entirety  to  IIFF  as 
subordinated  debt.  The  proposed  equity  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) will be contributed to pay IIFF’s periodic 
calls  on  capital  and  will  be  contributed  pro  rata  with  the 
contributions  of  all  other  shareholders.  ADB  will  subscribe  a 
maximum 20% of IIFF’s total paid-up capital. 
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector: Finance 
Subsector: Finance sector development 
Themes: Economic growth, governance, private sector 
development 
Subthemes: Widening access to markets and economic 
opportunities, economic and financial governance, public–private 
partnerships 
   
Environment  The investments are classified as category F1 with respect to 
Assessment  ADB’s Environment Policy (2002), and category C with respect to 
ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995) and ADB’s Policy 
on Indigenous Peoples (1998). The shareholders’ agreement will 
require IIFF to establish and maintain an environment and social 
management  system  (ESMS)  and  implement  procedures  that 
comply with ADB’s environment and social safeguard policies. 
   
Investment Program  The  proposed  financing  of  IIFF  supports  the  Government  of 
Description  Indonesia’s objective to increase the flow of private investment 
into infrastructure projects to a level that is 6–7 times the current 
average level. This is a challenging goal. The financial projections 
developed for this transaction indicate that there is considerable 
untapped demand for long-tenor financing, however, and the lack 
of  this  product  has  significantly  constrained  the  sustained 
expansion  of  infrastructure  investment  in  Indonesia.  It  is  in 
response to this perceived demand that an institutional response, 
tentatively  named  IIFF,  was  conceived  in  2007.  IIFF  was 
conceptualized as a nonbanking financial institution incorporated 
as a limited liability company, with a target fund base of about $1 
billion  in  5  years  from  the  commencement  of  operations  and 
estimated to grow to about $4.4 billion by year 10. IIFF will finance 
commercially viable infrastructure projects in Indonesia by offering

ii 
long-term debt denominated in local or foreign currency and by 
providing the intellectual capital needed to catalyze public–private 
partnerships  in  such  projects.  To  help  finance  infrastructure 
projects structured as public-private partnerships (PPPs), IIFF will 
seek  financial  participation  by  pension  funds,  insurance 
companies, institutions, and new investor classes that can provide 
long-term sources of finance. IIFF will proactively seek, establish, 
and develop relationships with regional and local governments 
and  take  on  the  development  of  projects  promoted  by  these 
governments to generate fee-based income in the initial years of 
its  operations.  IIFF  will  be  able  to  capitalize  on  its  early 
involvement  in  advising  the  Government  and  other  parties  in 
relation to developing infrastructure projects to generate funding 
opportunities.  
   
Rationale  Infrastructure is a critical area of emphasis for the Government 
and ADB to support Indonesia’s economic growth and poverty 
reduction strategies. Given increasingly significant infrastructure 
shortages and bottlenecks, infrastructure investments are critically 
needed  to  avoid  power  outages  and  relieve  transportation 
bottlenecks. Two key issues include a lack of infrastructure project 
development skills (most notably at the local government level) 
and a lack of long-term corporate debt to finance infrastructure 
projects  in  the  private  sector.  Deficiencies  in  the  regulatory 
frameworks for public-private partnerships are being addressed 
under ADB’s Infrastructure Reform Sector Development Program 
(IRSDP) Cluster (2005–2010). As such, there is a critical need for 
an institution like IIFF that can be a focal point for infrastructure 
project  development,  and  particularly  at  the  local  government 
level.  While  providing  long-term  debt  and  equity  financing  to 
infrastructure  projects  in  cooperation  with  local  financial 
institutions, IIFF could, through credit enhancements and other 
innovative products, also provide comfort to lenders and investors 
adequate  for  their  participation  in  infrastructure  development. 
IIFF’s exposure to infrastructure projects that are solely developed 
by the public sector (including state-owned enterprises) will be 
limited to a maximum 20% of IIFF’s overall lending portfolio. ADB 
is aware of the potential conflict of interest that may arise with 
respect  to  IIFF’s  joint  mandate  to  both  provide  development 
advice to government and financial support to the projects that 
may be structured based on this advice, and it will ensure that 
IIFF adopts policies and procedures that resolve and mitigate this 
potential conflict.  
   
Justification for ADB  ADB’s resources for financing private sector infrastructure projects 
Investment  are  limited.  IIFF  presents  an  opportunity  for  ADB  to  leverage 
those resources in Indonesia, where infrastructure shortages are 
critical and national government funds are limited. The approach 
is  based  upon  ADB’s  successful  support  of  Infrastructure 
Development Finance Company Limited (IDFC) in India. ADB’s 
financing support for IDFC was intended to be a model for other

iii
developing member countries seeking institutional arrangements 
to  stimulate  infrastructure  sector  reform,  private  sector 
participation in infrastructure finance, and domestic debt market 
development. IIFF will directly address the needs for infrastructure 
expertise in developing infrastructure at the local government level 
in particular, while providing the needed longer-term financing to 
both the public and private parties involved in commercially viable 
infrastructure projects. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The Project is expected to support Indonesia's economic growth 
and poverty reduction. The expected outcome will be financing of 
commercially  viable  infrastructure  projects  in  Indonesia  and 
providing structuring development advice to the Government and 
private sector developers. This will be done by providing financial 
assistance  via  debt  instruments,  equity  investments,  or 
guarantees. It will provide such financing to infrastructure projects 
that are structured, or capable of being structured, as PPPs or 
other bankable structures. IIFF will promote project development 
frameworks that support PPPs. Like ADB, IIFF will wish to ensure 
that  it  does  not  crowd  out  the  private  sector  in  providing  its 
financial assistance, and it will be concerned to diversify its risk 
across  a  broad  portfolio  of  Indonesian  infrastructure  projects. 
Accordingly, ADB will ensure that IIFF limits its net exposure to 
any project to a maximum 20% of project cost. On this basis, IIFF 
is expected to finance infrastructure projects with an aggregate 
project cost of up to $5 billion in the first 5 years of its operations. 
Enhanced private sector participation through PPPs will contribute 
to containing and eventually reducing Indonesia’s fiscal deficit.   
   
Investment Plan   IIFF  expects  to  begin  its  operations  with  up  to  $30  million  in 
financing of projects booked in the initial year, which is projected 
to grow to about $1 billion by the end of the fifth year. This is 
proposed to be met by a debt component of about $750 million 
(being a mixture of tier 2 capital and long-term senior debt) and an 
equity component of $200 million.  
   
Financing Plan  The proposed ADB investment of up to $140 million will comprise 
about 14% of the total financing projected to be needed as of the 
end of year 5 (2013). As financial assistance will comprise an 
equity  investment  of  up  to  a  maximum  of  $40  million  and  a 
sovereign loan of up to $100 million to Indonesia for relending to 
PTSMI, which in turn will onlend these funds to IIFF. ADB will, 
over a 5-year period, subscribe for a maximum 20% of the shares 
of IIFF. The terms of ADB’s loan agreement with the Government 
and, in turn, the Government’s subsidiary loan agreement with 
PTSMI  will  require  that  the  amount  of  any  loan  disbursed  to 
PTSMI be onlent by PTSMI as subordinated loans to IIFF.

Facility Amount and  (i) Equity. ADB will make an equity investment of up to the lesser 
Terms  of the rupiah equivalent of $40 million and 20% of the total paid-up 
equity capital of IIFF. ADB will ensure that it is at no time the 
largest single shareholder in IIFF.  
 
(ii) Loan.  Government Regulation 66/2007 as amended on 16 
December 2008 by Government regulation 75/2008, provides for 
state  equity  participation  through  a  fully  government-owned 
holding company. PTSMI will be set up for this purpose. PTSMI 
will then invest in the equity capital of IIFF. A loan of $100 million 
from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources  will  be  provided  to 
Indonesia for relending to PTSMI. The loan will be provided under 
ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending 
facility. The loan will have a 25-year term including a grace period 
of 5 years, an interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s 
LIBOR-based lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per 
annum, and such other terms and conditions as are set forth in 
the negotiated draft loan agreement. (A similar loan from World 
Bank loan is proposed for 24.5 years at LIBOR + 75 basis points 
with no commitment charges.) It is envisaged that Indonesia will 
relend the ADB loan of $100 million to PTSMI in rupiah. Under the 
terms of the subsidiary loan agreement with Indonesia, PTSMI 
will, in turn, lend all such disbursed amounts in their entirety to 
IIFF as subordinated debt on terms to be mutually agreed. 
Period of Utilization  The loan and equity investment funds will each be available for a

v
5-year disbursement period after all conditions for disbursement 
or, as the case may be, subscriptions are met. The last date for 
any disbursement under the loan or equity will be 31 December 
2013.   
   
Estimated Loan Closing  31 December 2013 
Date 
   
Implementation  The Directorate General of State Assets Management, Ministry of 
Arrangements  Finance, will be the Executing Agency for the sovereign loan.  
   
Procurement  Procurement of all goods financed under the ADB loan will be 
carried  out  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines 
(2007, as amended from time to time). 
   
Project Benefits and  On  the  demand  side,  there  is  a  well-established  need  for 
Beneficiaries  infrastructure  investment  based  on  the  current  indicators  of 
service  coverage  and  quality,  comparison  with  historical 
investment  levels,  and  the  need  to  accelerate  infrastructure 
investment  to  sustain  high  growth  and  economic  expansion 
needed for poverty reduction. The benefits to society arising out of 
improved  and  more  equitable  access  to  infrastructure  and  the 
strong  linkages  between  economic  growth  and  investment  in 
infrastructure  are  all  well  established  on  the  basis  of  global 
experience. These factors taken together represent the demand-
side business case for setting up IIFF. 
 
On the supply side, it is clear the Indonesian banks that dominate 
the country’s financial system are not in a position to provide long-
tenor loans for infrastructure projects. The limited development of 
domestic  capital  markets  means  very  few  developers  of 
infrastructure projects have the option of disintermediation (i.e., 
directly tapping the financial markets for long-tenor debt funding 
by  issuing  bonds  or  other  debt  instruments).  Thus,  there  is  a 
definite need for long-tenor loans for infrastructure projects that 
are currently not available in the Indonesian context, and this by 
itself  provides  a  basis  for  setting  up  IIFF.  There  are  similar 
constraints in mobilizing domestic savings directly for funding the 
required equity investments in infrastructure projects. This would 
thus address the current supply-side constraints and facilitate the 
flow of funds to infrastructure projects in Indonesia. 
 
In addition to a scarcity of direct financing, Indonesia’s financial 
system  presently  lacks  unfunded  credit  enhancement  and  risk 
management  products  for  large  infrastructure/PPP  projects. 
Based on its established skills in this segment and its superior 
understanding of the risks involved, IIFF can offer guarantees to 
address this gap. Other innovative funding mechanisms will be 
available through cofinancing, refinancing and take-out financing, 
mezzanine financing, and securitization (long-term opportunities). 
IIFF will also play a strategic role in project development, helping

vi 
clients to structure PPP projects in a manner that creates investor 
interest and establishes credibility for the project.  
   
Risk and Safeguards  ADB has conducted a due diligence in relation to the proposed 
investment. Documentation of the equity investment is scheduled 
to  commence  as  soon  as  possible.  The  main  risks  described 
below are regarded as acceptable for an investment of this kind. 
 
(i) Economic and political risks. Looking ahead, the economic 
outlook foresees many challenges. Significant adverse effects of 
the global financial turmoil have emerged since September 2008. 
Government bond yields spiked to 20% by end-October 2008, as 
foreign investors reduced exposures while market liquidity dried 
up. The Jakarta stock index fell by 30% in October 2008 (by more 
than  50%  since  the  beginning  of  the  year).  The  rupiah  has 
depreciated  by  more  that  30%  since  September  2008  despite 
heavy intervention by Bank Indonesia. Continued weakness in 
commodity prices and tighter financing conditions would depress 
exports  and  investment  going  forward.  However,  increased 
exchange rate flexibility, adequate reserve levels, improved export 
diversity,  and  declining  external  debt  should  limit  the  potential 
impact of negative external shocks. While risks and uncertainties 
remain,  continued  good  economic  management  will  ensure 
gradual  restoration  of  full  macroeconomic  stability.  Further 
progress  in  structural  reforms  and  in  removing  infrastructure 
investment bottlenecks would also help mitigate the impact of a 
global slowdown. 
 
(ii)  Regulatory  and  project  development  risk.  Much  of  the 
difficulty with infrastructure finance in Indonesia originates from 
constraints  in  the  policy,  regulatory,  and  project  development 
facilities. Reform of these constraints is critical to IIFF’s long-term 
success. The complementary programs as stated in paras. 33–34 
of  the  text  are  expected  to  relieve  these  constraints.  The 
Government  recognizes  the  need  to  continue  the  policy  and 
regulatory  reform  process  together  with  accelerated  project 
development  activities.  In  addition,  other  projects  will  become 
bankable with IIFF’s introducing appropriate types of financing or 
credit  enhancements.  IIFF  will  also  directly  contribute  to  this 
accelerated process through its project development and policy 
advisory roles. 
 
(iii) Commencement risk. As a start-up company, IIFF faces risks 
associated with implementation of a business plan by a company 
with  no  preexisting  business.  It  further  seeks  to  multiply  the 
existing Indonesian deal flow by a factor of five to seven within a 
space  of  5  years.  Accordingly,  IIFF  faces  the  risks  that  (a) 
demand for financial assistance and for fee-based services may 
be lower than projected; and (b) implementation of the necessary 
policies and procedures, staff recruitment, and other operational 
matters may take longer than anticipated. In all cases, these risks

vii
could impact on IIFF’s business and, as a result, on the projected 
disbursement of ADB’s loan and the contribution of its equity. 
However, the business plan has been prepared in a conservative 
manner based on a realistic assessment of the potential project 
pipeline. The Government is also preparing 10 new national-level 
PPP projects, to be available for financing under the PPP mode. 
The  provision  of  fee-based  services  is  believed  to  offer 
considerable revenue buffer in the early years and will assist in 
building up a strong pipeline. Financial losses associated with 
commencement risk are mitigated through capital inflows being 
subject to call. Under this structure, ADB will only be required to 
subscribe for $2 million of equity at inception, with future funding 
calls  conditional  upon  satisfactory  establishment  of  IIFF  and 
achievement of certain performance milestones. 
 
(iv)  Funding  risk.  By  the  time  IIFF  is  established,  if  the 
participation of further investors’ (i.e. investors other than PTSMI, 
IFC, ADB, and KfW/DEG) is less than 15% of the total shares in 
IIFF, PTSMI will subscribe for additional shares to take up that 
portion  of  the  equity  not  acquired  by  such  investors.  It  is 
envisaged  that  PTSMI’s  share  ownership  may  exceed  30%  if 
further  investors  subscribe  for  anything  less  than  a  15% 
shareholding in IIFF, but its voting rights will in any event be 
limited to 30% and it will be obligated to endeavor to dilute down 
to 30% ownership as such further investors subscribe for shares.  
 
(v) Asset quality risk. IIFF, as a project financier, will be exposed 
to the credit risk of its borrowers. This risk will be mitigated by 
IIFF’s adopting market-based lending systems incorporating risk 
management and credit review processes consistent with best 
practices in private sector banks and by recruiting a professional 
management team. IIFF will provide financial assistance using 
project finance structures common in the industry. These will, to 
the  extent  possible,  be  conditioned  on  adequate  security  and 
other recourse arrangements mitigating IIFF’s losses in the event 
that projects are unable to support their debt service obligations.  
 
(vi) Management risk. Senior management is being recruited for 
IIFF. IFC has engaged an international head-hunting company to 
help  select  the  chief  executive  officer  (CEO).  Critical  are  the 
international  competitive  governance  arrangements  initiated  up 
front  in  the  shareholder  agreements  and  the  Government’s 
commitment  to  allow  fully  commercial  operations  based  upon 
internationally accepted standards. In this regard, the Government 
has committed to keep its shareholding such that, both directly 
and indirectly, it will hold around 30% of IIFF’s subscribed shares. 
Highly skilled staff will be required to manage IIFF. Such skills will 
be sought through searches for all senior management and any 
independent board members. Competitive salaries and benefits 
will be paid. This risk is mitigated by the commitment of all funding 
shareholders to hire the best candidates on the market.

viii 
 
(vii) Risk of conflict of interest. IIFF’s business plan proposes 
that IIFF offer both advisory services to government in relation to 
the structuring of selected projects and financial assistance to the 
same  projects.  This  strategy,  unless  carefully  controlled  and 
managed using information firewalls that are clear both internally 
and externally, exposes IIFF and, potentially, its shareholders to 
the risk of reputational damage. ADB will ensure that IIFF sets up 
robust information firewalls and implements procedures to assure 
that  its  position  vis-à-vis  co-lenders  and  government  is  fully 
disclosed.  
 
(viii) Exit risk. ADB plans to exit from its investment in IIFF either 
via a private sale to a third party or via an initial public offering 
(IPO) of shares, in either case within a period of approximately 10 
years from the date of its initial investment. Although the stock 
markets in Indonesia have made great progress since the 1990s, 
they  are  not  as  developed  as  those  of  other  countries  in  the 
region. A variety of factors can affect the Indonesian financial 
markets in general and IIFF’s preparation for an IPO in particular. 
In addition, the current financial crisis may result in a delay in the 
IPO, making ADB’s investment difficult to manage. This risk can 
be mitigated by identifying and negotiating an exit sale with a 
third-party buyer.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan of up to $100 million for the Indonesian Infrastructure Financing Facility Company (IIFF) 
Project, and (ii) a proposed equity investment of up to the equivalent of $40 million (in rupiah 
equivalent) in the equity capital of IIFF in Indonesia. 
 
II.  BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 
A.  Indonesian Economy 
 
2.  Indonesia has witnessed a strong economic expansion since recovering from the 1997 
Asian financial crisis. In 2007, economic growth accelerated to a 10-year high of 6.3% despite a 
slowing global economy. Even with unstable global financial markets and a slowing world 
economy,  Indonesia  did  not  experience  a  growth  slowdown  in  the  first  half  of  2008  and 
economic  growth  remained  respectable  at  6.1  percent  in  the  third  quarter.  In  contrast  to 
previous years, unemployment declined from 10.3% in 2006 to 8.3% in 2008. Poverty has been 
successfully cut to precrisis levels, and stable macroeconomic policies are firmly in place. These 
achievements are especially noteworthy against the backdrop of a number of natural disasters, 
including the tsunami of December 2004 in Aceh, the Nias earthquake of March 2005, the May 
2006 earthquake in Yogyakarta and Central Java, and the July 2006 earthquake and tsunami in 
West Java. While private investment has also picked up (the Investment Board reports that 
realized foreign investment nearly doubled from $5.9 billion in 2006 to $10.4 billion in 2007), 
governance  issues  (most  notably  in  the  decentralization  area)  remain  an  impediment  to 
improving  the  investment  climate  and  need  to  be  addressed  to  facilitate  infrastructure 
investments critical for Indonesia’s longer-term growth prospects.  
 
3.  Like its Asian neighbors, Indonesia confronted significant inflationary pressures in 2008. 
Inflation accelerated from the beginning of the year to reach 11% in June 2008, driven primarily 
by external factors related to escalating international food prices and a domestic fuel price 
adjustment. To stabilize price expectations, from May 2008 Bank Indonesia raised the Bank 
Indonesia rate, its reference rate, six times by 25 basis points to 9.5%. Inflation peaked at 12% 
in the third quarter of 2008. Following the tightening of monetary policy and falling commodity 
prices as the global economy started to show recessionary conditions, inflation eased to 11% at 
year-end  2008.  Assuming  that  price  expectations  are  stabilized  and  there  is  continued 
moderation of international food and energy prices, inflation should begin to decline in 2009 
toward Bank Indonesia’s target range of 3.5–5.5%. 
 
4.  The Government almost balanced the budget in 2008.  An early estimate of central 
government budget outturn for 2008 suggests that the budget deficit is reduced to 0.1 percent of 
GDP,  compared  to  1.3  percent  of  GDP  in  2007.  The  improvement  in  the  Government’s 
budgetary position reflects continued fiscal discipline, policy actions to address energy subsidies, 
and significant progress in improving tax collections. In May 2008, the Government raised 
subsidized fuel prices by an average of 29 percent, relieving some of the budgetary burden of 
soaring  oil  prices.  Improvement  in  tax  administrations  has  led  to  significant  growth  in 
government revenue collection since late 2007. The debt-to-GDP ratio has declined to about 
30% in 2008. The Government is aware that, if the remaining subsidies are not reversed over 
the medium term, increased allocation for subsidies could crowd out higher priority investments 
in the social and infrastructure areas, where investments are needed to sustain Indonesia’s 
longer-term growth and development objectives. Going forward, as international oil prices are 
expected to remain volatile and difficult to predict, the Government remains committed to the 
longer-term goal of setting energy prices at economic or market rates to promote efficiency and

2 
safeguard the fiscal position. The current moderation in international oil prices will provide a 
good opportunity to promote the policy. 
 
5.  Indonesia’s financial sector has remained resilient in the face of the global credit market 
turmoil. This resilience is underpinned by improvements in most indicators. The sector remains 
healthy overall. The net nonperforming loan ratio markedly improved from 7% in 2006 to 4% as 
of November 2008. Risk-weighted capital of all big banks is well above the minimum regulatory 
threshold.  Private  credit  growth  had  been  accelerating  through  November  2008,  reaching 
almost 35% year on year, but it has slowed since. The financial sector has nevertheless been 
adversely impacted by that turbulence, including by the sharp drop in bond prices. Domestic 
liquidity  has  tightened  significantly,  reflecting  both  the  earlier  rapid  credit  growth  and  the 
deteriorating global conditions. Reports are that access to trade finance has also become more 
difficult. (One commercial bank experienced operating difficulties in October 2008, and Bank 
Indonesia  took  swift  action  to  transfer  management  of  the  bank  to  the  Deposit  Insurance 
Corporation). 
 
6.  Looking ahead, the economic outlook foresees many challenges. Significant adverse 
effects from the global financial turmoil have emerged since September 2008. Government 
bond yields spiked to 20% by end-October 2008, as foreign investors reduced exposures while 
market liquidity dried up. The Jakarta stock index fell by 30% in October 2008 (by more than 
50% since the beginning of the year). The rupiah has depreciated by more than 30% since 
September  2008  despite  heavy  intervention  by  Bank  Indonesia.  Continued  weakness  in 
commodity prices and tighter financing conditions would depress exports and investment going 
forward. External economic conditions in 2009 are likely to remain difficult. However, increased 
exchange  rate  flexibility,  adequate  reserve  levels,  improved  export  diversity,  and  declining 
external debt should limit the potential impact of negative external shocks. While risks and 
uncertainties remain, continued good economic management will ensure the gradual restoration 
of  full  macroeconomic  stability.  Further  progress  in  structural  reforms  and  in  removing 
bottlenecks  to  infrastructure,  investment  would  also  help  mitigate  the  impact  of  a  global 
slowdown. This makes the establishment of IIFF even more vital in order to catalyze those 
needed infrastructure investments.

B.  Infrastructure  Development  in  Indonesia  and  the  Need  for  Public–Private 
Partnerships 
 
7.  In Indonesia, investment in infrastructure, which had averaged 5–6% of GDP per annum 
prior to 1997, slumped to less than 2% in 2000 and has subsequently risen to 3–3.5% of GDP in 
recent years. Despite the overall improvement in infrastructure spending, the composition of this 
investment (public versus private) requires attention (Figure 1). Investment levels improved 
especially on the back of huge public investments. This is corroborated by the fact that, even 
during 2005–2007, the Government had increased allocations to infrastructure. In contrast, 
private investment has remained low in the postcrisis period and it declined significantly to 
below 1% between 2000 and 2006.

8.  It is widely recognized that only in the last 5 years has Indonesia reached a stage where 
the Government can shift its focus from the restoration of macroeconomic stability that was 
dictated by the 1997 crisis to long-term issues of development. In October 2004, the current 
Government established the following ambitious macroeconomic targets in its medium-term 
development program to be achieved by the end of its term in 2009: (i) accelerate GDP growth 
from 4.5% in 2003 to 7.6% (for an annual average of 6.6%), (ii) increase the investment-GDP 
ratio from 20.5% in 2003 to 28.4%, (iii) reduce the unemployment rate from 9.7% in 2004 to 
5.1%,  and (iv)  halve  the  poverty  rate  from  16.6%  in  2004  to  8.2%.  From  the  outset,  the 
Government identified acceleration of infrastructure development as essential for achieving 
these  macroeconomic  targets  and  gave  high  priority  to  increasing access  to  infrastructure 
services and improving the quality of these services. Since it was obvious that the estimated 
investment  requirements  would  far  exceed  the  available  public  sector  funding  (including 
multilateral and bilateral aid), the Government called for major private sector participation (PSP) 
to bridge the gap. Public-private partnerships (PPPs), which are long-term contracts signed by 
public  agencies  (federal,  regional,  or  local)  and  private  partners  for  the  construction, 
refurbishment, operation, and maintenance of the infrastructure network, were chosen as the 
preferred approach for increasing PSP. The main needs motivating governments to enter into 
PPPs  for  infrastructure  normally  are  to:  (i)  attract  private  capital  investment;  (ii)  increase 
efficiency  and  use  available  resources  more  effectively;  and  (iii)  reform  sectors  through  a 
relocation of roles, incentives, and accountability. 
 
9.  Given  the  projected  GDP  growth  at  5.5%  and  above,  it  is  generally  accepted  that 
infrastructure  investment  of  7–8%  of  GDP  would  be  required  over  the  period  2005–2009, 
amounting to about $65 billion. Of this, public investment is expected to amount to $25 billion 
(38%), while $14 billion (22%) is expected to come from domestic banks and insurance and 
pension funds, $10 billion (15%) from multilateral and bilateral development partners, and $16 
billion (25%) from domestic and foreign private sector investors. Thus, a considerable gap exists 
between the needs for investment from the private sector and that sector’s historical exposures. 
 
10.  Although a review of the normative estimates of infrastructure investment requirements 
suggests the opportunity for infrastructure financing is potentially large, this conclusion assumes 
a dynamic scenario and not a business-as-usual approach. This dynamic scenario will entail a 
six- to eight-fold increase in private sector participation in an environment of a swiftly reforming 
infrastructure sector, and, as project preparation has been an issue, significant resources will 
have to be channeled into project preparation to ensure the emergence of bankable PPP 
projects.  The  Government  has  identified  infrastructure  development  as  a  key  element  of 
national  policy  and  initiated  reform  measures  and  progressive  legislation  to  facilitate 
infrastructure development (para. 16). In February 2006, it released the infrastructure policy 
package listing 50 actions completed in 2005 and 153 actions to be implemented during 2006. 
This was followed by formulation of the Infrastructure Reform Sector Development Program 
(IRSDP)1 by the Government and the three funding agencies, using the infrastructure policy 
package as the starting point and expanding the reforms until 2010. In February 2007, a further 
policy package was released by the Government in the form of presidential instruction 6/2007, 
covering reforms planned until the end of 2007 in six areas, including infrastructure. Finally, 
Presidential Instructions 5/2008, released in May 2008, contain detailed reform actions and

11.  In further response to the aforementioned challenge, an institutional response tentatively 
named the Indonesian Infrastructure Financing Facility (IIFF) was conceived in 2007. Broadly, 
IIFF was envisaged as a new national-level institution that could facilitate the flow of private 
funding into infrastructure projects in Indonesia by making long-term funding available for such 
projects  and  establishing  credible  frameworks  to  attract  investment  flows  from  various 
categories of private sector investors. The Government still has a major role to play in catalyzing 
this change, however. 
 
C.  Evolution of Public–Private Partnerships in Indonesia 
 
12.  Indonesia has undergone four different phases of private participation in infrastructure 
development over the past three decades. An initial attempt with PPPs was made in the 1980s, 
with the most notable project being an elevated toll road that now forms part of Jakarta’s inner 
ring road and connects to its main port. Then the precrisis 1990s saw investment bankers lining 
up to participate in independent power producer and toll road projects, albeit usually based 
more upon political connections than clear and impartial judgments as to the associated risks, 
benefits, and costs. As a result, the public sector absorbed a disproportionate share of the risks. 
In addition, no concerted effort was made to address the various policy, legal, and institutional 
impediments facing the infrastructure sectors. After the crisis, government efforts focused on 
risk  mitigation  by  renegotiating  and  canceling  major  infrastructure  contracts  signed  in  the 
previous years rather than on removing those impediments. This was followed by the onset of 
the financial crisis in mid-1997, which put several public and private infrastructure projects on 
hold and abruptly ended what might be termed the “direct political appointment” model. The 
most recent development comprised 91 PPP projects tabled at the Indonesia Infrastructure 
Summit (2005) and Presidential Decree 67, the sunrise PPP legislation that was enacted. 
  
13.  The key impediments to the evolution of private sector financing and PPPs were lack of 
good governance; inadequate project preparation; poor regulatory frameworks; an absence of 
transparent bidding procedures; unavailability of long-term, local-currency financing at fixed 
interest rates; and the currency crisis that aggravated the dollar-denominated financing for most 
infrastructure projects in the precrisis period. 
 
14.  It thus emerges that Indonesia’s limited experience with competitively tendered projects, 
lack of nonrecourse financing, and state-owned enterprise (SOE) centric infrastructure program 
provide a challenging starting point. Nevertheless, a purposeful reform program coupled with 
advancing the project-finance model to secure revenue streams can make an impact.  
 
D.  Constraints on Infrastructure Financing 
 
15.  Infrastructure financing in Indonesia still suffers from the lack of long-tenor finance that is 
required to fund long-term infrastructure concessions. The banking and financial sector has 
emerged from the post crisis, and structural improvements are visible across important areas of 
activity. Nevertheless, the constraints on infrastructure financing still remain.  
(i)  Banks.  Long-tenor  financing  remains  difficult  since  deposits  maturing  in  6 
months or less account for more than 90% of time deposit and banks are the 
primary source of infrastructure finance. Moreover, bank financing has limited 
applicability in the infrastructure financing context, given the fact that banks are 
constrained by single-borrower exposure limits, industry-exposure limits, asset-
liability  mismatches,  and  prudential  banking  norms.  As  such,  long-term

6 
borrowings  are  severely  limited  and  so  is  long-term  financing.  Indonesia’s 
financial system assets remain dominated (about 78% in 2006) by the banking 
system. The large presence of the banking sector (130 commercial and 1,822 
rural banks, as of July 2007), however, has yet to grow in scale compared with 
other  countries.  When  compared  to  other  nations  in  the  region,  Indonesian 
banking lags by assets size as a percentage of GDP. Therefore, although 78% of 
the total assets in the Indonesian financial system are bank dominated, the 
banking sector itself is small in relation to GDP. Based on the maturity profile of 
bank deposits, banks in Indonesia face a major mismatch between the profiles of 
their  assets  and  liabilities.  Infrastructure  accounted  for  just  11%  of  the 
outstanding bank credit as of November 2007. In absolute terms, total bank 
lending to infrastructure sectors was Rp109.7 trillion ($12.2 billion) out of the total 
bank credit of Rp962.4 trillion ($106.9 billion). 
(ii)  Bond  market.  The Government bond market has developed well, and such 
bonds are held mainly by banks, insurance companies, and pension funds (about 
70%). Nevertheless, only a few large corporate entities have access to bonds as 
a source of fund mobilization. As in the case of bank loans, the tenors of bonds 
are generally shorter than what is suitable for infrastructure projects with long 
gestation periods. The average tenor of bonds is 5–7 years, and only few large 
corporate entities are able to raise debt for tenors over 10 years. Only investment 
grade bonds can be publicly listed, and these have tax exemptions on interest 
that benefit institutional investors like pension funds, commercial banks, and 
mutual funds. No such tax exemption is available for unlisted bonds, which carry 
higher  coupon  rates  to  reflect  greater  liquidity  risk.  Private  sector  corporate 
bonds accounted for 13% of the total value of bonds listed on the Indonesia 
Stock Exchange in 2006.  
(iii)  Equity markets. The equity markets are small and still in the development stage, 
providing direct access to risk capital for only a handful of Indonesian companies. 
Retail interest in the equity market is limited. The Indonesian equity market is 
relatively concentrated and not very liquid. Although there were 344 companies 
listed as of the end of 2006, the top 10 companies accounted for 48% of the 
market capitalization and 47% of the total trading turnover in 2007.  
(iv)  Contractual savings institutions. Among pension funds, state-owned entities 
(Asabri, Jamsostek, and Taspen) dominate. Private pension funds are growing 
rapidly,  albeit  from  a  small  base.  Despite  their  access  to  long-term  assets, 
pension funds are heavily invested in government bonds and bank deposits. The 
insurance industry is fragmented, with a large number of small players whose 
solvency often is questionable. The current coverage of insurance is low and 
lapse rates high.  
(v)  Mutual funds. The mutual fund industry has shown rapid growth, with retail 
investors  shifting  their  preference  from  bank  deposits  to  mutual  funds  that 
invested mainly in government securities. The industry is dominated by income-
oriented funds that invest in debt instruments rather than equity. 
(vi)  Credit enhancement and risk management products. Indonesia’s financial 
system  presently  lacks  non-fund  based  credit  enhancement  and  risk 
management products for PPP projects.  
 
E.  Enabling Environment for Public–Private Partnerships  
 
16.  Indonesia has undertaken a sustained set of measures aimed at creating an enabling 
environment  for  PPP.  There  are  ongoing  initiatives  relating  to  the  policy  and  regulatory 
framework that provide a strong foundation for an entity like the proposed IIFF to commence

7 
operations. These initiatives of the Government are being supported by official development 
assistance through program loans like the IRSDP, funded by the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB)  (footnote  1)  and  Japan  Bank  for  International  Cooperation,  and  the  World  Bank’s 
Infrastructure Development Policy Loan. These have helped to identify the key constraints to be 
addressed and set out time-bound targets for implementing various initiatives. While these 
initiatives are ongoing, a number of significant steps have been taken in the last 3–4 years that 
are  expected  to  help  create  an  enabling  environment  for  PPP  in  Indonesia.  Some  key 
developments are: 
(i)  Framework  for  private  sector  participation.  Presidential  Decree  67/2005, 
notified  in  November  2005,  provides  a  general  framework  for  PSP  in 
infrastructure.  This  legislation  identifies  two  forms  of  PSP  (partnership  and 
licensing)  and  specifies  that  the  private  sector  sponsors  must  be  selected 
through open and transparent bidding. Further, it specifies that tariffs have to be 
set for full cost recovery and provides for a subsidy to cover public service 
obligations (PSOs) where the tariffs exceed the consumers’ ability to pay. 
(ii)  Institutional  structure.  The  institutional  structure  within  the  Government  for 
dealing with PPP projects has been reinforced through legislation. Presidential 
Decree 42/2005 strengthened the National Committee for the Acceleration of 
Infrastructure Provision (KKPPI)2 as a high-level entity advising the President on 
infrastructure (detailed in para. 34). Coordinating Ministry for Economic Affairs 
(CMEA) Regulation 1/2006 supports the KKPPI by providing for the creation of 
the KKPPI Secretariat spread across the CMEA and the National Development 
Planning  Agency  (BAPPENAS).  CMEA  Regulation  4/2006  specifies  the 
evaluation process to be followed for PPP projects requiring the Government’s 
support. For the last 2 years, ADB has provided necessary capacity building and 
advisory  support  to  the  BAPPENAS  part  of  the  KKPPI  Secretariat  through 
technical assistance (TA)3 while the CMEA part has been supported by the World 
Bank’s Private Provision of Infrastructure Technical Assistance Loan. For the 
day-to-day coordination and management of PPP transactions as their number 
increases,  a  network  consisting  of  a  central  PPP  unit  under  the  KKPPI 
Secretariat and PPP nodes in the line ministries have been partly developed. 
(iii)  Risk management framework. Ministry of Finance (MOF) Regulation 38/2006 
provides for the creation of a risk management unit within MOF to identify and 
allocate risks relating to PPP projects. MOF has played an important role in 
developing and implementing the framework as an instrument for assessing, 
pricing, monitoring, and managing contingent liabilities that arise from selective 
guarantees for PPP projects against risks related to policies and performance of 
the  Government  and  its  agencies.  Under  IRSDP  subprogram  1,  Regulation 
38/2006 on risk management policy was issued to ensure that risks of individual 
PPP projects were appropriately allocated between the public and private sectors 
and that the Government’s overall exposure was well managed. The policy’s 
declared objective was to support infrastructure development while maintaining 
fiscal sustainability of the government budget. To implement Regulation 38/2006, 
a permanent Risk Management Unit was established in MOF. That unit has been 
fully  operationalized  in  terms  of  functions,  budget,  staffing,  and  operational 
procedures, with support provided through the TA attached to the IRSDP. In the 
2008 budget, Rp745 billion has been allocated to such support for toll roads and

Rp300 billion for power projects. An initial allocation of Rp1.05 trillion has been 
provided for the newly established Government Investment Center,4 and a policy 
paper has been prepared by MOF on a Guarantee Fund to provide backing for 
government  support,  with  the  view  to  establishing  the  Fund  under  IRSDP 
subprogram 3. 
(iv)  Project preparation. Given the weaknesses in project preparation that have 
impeded execution of PPP transactions, establishment of a project development 
facility (PDF) has been given priority under subprogram 2 of the IRSDP. After a 
slow start, the PDF is now fully operational and the pipeline of national and 
regional  projects  seeking  its  funding  for  feasibility  studies  and  transaction 
advisory services is growing.5 
(v)  Sector regulation. The Government has established new, though not yet fully 
independent, regulatory bodies for toll roads, the downstream part of the oil and 
gas sector, telecommunications, and water supply and sanitation. These bodies 
have become operational in terms of budget, staffing, functions, and standard 
operating procedures. In addition, a similar collaborative approach supported by 
TA (footnote 3) has been adopted to review current practices and arrangements 
in  all  infrastructure  sectors  and  to  formulate  short-  and  medium-term 
recommendations for strengthening sector regulation. The key recommendation 
is to aim at having in each sector an independent regulator with the following 
economic functions: (a) setting (approving) tariffs and other service charges; (b) 
establishing standards for the terms and conditions of providing services; (c) 
making and enforcing market rules for the sector; (d) monitoring economic and 
management performance of the regulated entities; (e) issuing, reviewing, and 
canceling  licenses;  (f)  reviewing  concession  agreements;  and  (g)  arbitrating 
disputes within the sector. The development of such independent regulators will 
require time and is unlikely to occur within the remaining IRSDP time frame. 
Nevertheless,  various  short-term  recommendations  to  move  toward  the 
introduction of internationally recognized regulatory practices are planned under 
subprogram 3 of IRSDP. These include consolidating the existing regulatory 
functions  under  each  line  ministry,  building  the  line  ministries’  capacity  in 
regulatory  procedures,  creating  a  more  transparent  regulatory  environment, 
encouraging stakeholder participation in regulatory matters, and allowing tariffs to 
reach cost recovery levels. During this transition period, regulation by contract 
will play an important role for PPP projects. 
(vi)  Recent initiatives. Government Regulation 15/2005 addressed the governance 
issues  in  the  toll  road  sector  by  separating  the  regulatory  and  operational 
functions of Jasa Marga, the toll road SOE, and setting up a regulator (BPJT, the 
Indonesian Toll Road Authority). The Law on Shipping was passed by Parliament 
on 8 April 2008 and is expected to change the fundamental structure of the 
sector in the next 3 years, thus creating opportunities for private investors in the 
sector.  Among  such  other  measures  as  maritime  safety  and  security, 
harbormasters,  and  establishment  of  a  sea  and  coast  guard,  it  reflects 
decentralization and removes the SOE monopoly with a transition period of 3 
years. Thereafter, the PELINDOs I–IV (the state-owned seaport operators) will 
transfer their assets to the Government and will play only a role as port operators. 
Port  authorities  will  be  established  under  the  Directorate  General  of  Sea 
Transportation on a regional basis to act as regulators. Similarly, the aviation law

which deregulates the air transportation sector was approved in January 2009 by

(vii)  Land  acquisition.  Presidential  Decree  65/2006,  amending  the  earlier 
Presidential  Decree  36/2005,  addresses  issues  relating  to  land  acquisition. 
Together,  the  two  regulations  moved  the  Government’s  policies  on  land 
acquisition closer to internationally accepted principles on involuntary settlement, 
particularly with regard to provisions on the use of market prices and recognition 
of nonphysical losses. A national land agency, set up and funded to implement 
the Government’s decision to take on responsibility for land acquisition, marks a 
departure from the past practice of making the private sector sponsor responsible 
for land acquisition. A land working group chaired by the land agency is to review 
the current policy and implementation of land acquisition, as well as to prepare 
policy and operational recommendations and an action plan to accelerate the 
process while ensuring fair compensation. The objective is to formulate a long-
term approach—the so-called land banking through zoning and purchase—in 
order to secure land well in advance of tendering so as to avoid speculation. 
 
17.  Overall, it may be said that the Government has taken up in earnest the creation of an 
enabling environment for PPP projects. This process is expected to continue with assistance 
from the multilaterals and bilateral development agencies. While various infrastructure sectors 
differ in terms of their readiness for PPP projects, many sectors are currently at a stage where 
PPP projects may be expected to emerge over the next few years. 
 
F.   Potential Infrastructure Sector Investment Opportunities 
 
18.  The objective of evaluating individual sectors is rooted in the fact that a new institution 
like the IIFF necessarily must reflect and respond to the sectoral nuances of infrastructure 
prevalent in Indonesia. The sectoral analysis shows the factors that can stand in the way of 
creating bankable concessions in each sector. Therefore, a short description of the individual 
sectors is presented below.  
 
1.  Power 
 
19.  Power is a promising yet challenging sector, the promise being in the demand-supply 
gap that is waiting to be bridged. The Government estimates that between 2008 and 2018, there 
is an $84 billion requirement for generation, transmission, and distribution investment to keep 
pace with the growth in power demand which is set to rise by at least 9.5% per annum through 
2027. The central challenge in the power sector is the credit risk of the single off-taker, State  
Electricity Corporation (PLN), an SOE. The Constitutional Court ruled against proposals for 
unbundling and privatization in 2004, resulting in a setback to Indonesia’s power sector reform 
process. IIFF can explore a policy and advisory role in assisting the Government and PLN to 
revisit the scope for implementing PPPs in a manner that would obtain constitutional and 
government support. This would bring private sector finance to the forefront in the power sector. 
The other issue is the public service obligation (PSO) subsidy, which in 2008 came to almost $8 
billion. The PSO mechanism needs to be enshrined in a credible structure that will give private 
capital  confidence  to  invest  in  the  power  sector.  It  is  important  to  develop  a  few  model 
transactions that can establish early success stories. Realizing the need to offer better-prepared 
projects to potential investor-operators, the Government has selected two large model projects 
that were presented at the Infrastructure Conference in November 2006 (the 1,200 megawatt 
coal-based Central Java Project and a 500 MW gas-based project). The feasibility study for 
Central Java plant has been completed together with market sounding. The next step involves 
putting together a complete set of bidding documents. Having worked through all processes and

10 
negotiated all terms on this model project PLN will be able to use it as a template for further 
projects and thereby reduce the time necessary to bring these to financial close. 
 
2.  Telecommunications 
 
20.  This infrastructure sector is more advanced in terms of reforms than the others and is 
naturally progressing, without much external intervention, toward ever greater private sector 
participation. A key driver of this sector is the relatively low start-up investment costs. As in 
other countries, this is attributable to the technological advances driving the sector, as well as to 
the fact that its tariffs are less affected by political and social considerations. The two major 
enterprises—Telkom and Indosat—are listed on the Jakarta and New York stock exchanges, 
the Indonesian Telecommunications Regulatory Body (BRTI) established under the Ministry of 
Communications and Information is fully operational, and regulation 8/2006 on interconnection 
has allowed a move from revenue sharing to a cost-based approach for setting tariffs. The 
successful  recent  tendering  of  the  3G  frequency  suggests  that  the  Indonesian 
telecommunications  sector  is  capable  of  absorbing  more  advanced  models  of  competitive 
behavior and transparent contracting. To meet the growing demand for internet services, the 
Government  has  launched  the  ambitious  “Palapa  Ring”  project,  which  aims  to  link  Java, 
Kalimantan, Maluku, Nusa Tenggara, Papua, Sulawesi, Sumatra, and eight existing network 
connections or backhauls through an estimated total 35,280 kilometers of undersea and 21,870 
kilometers of underground fiber-optic cable. Components of the Palapa Ring project could 
potentially be financing opportunities for the IIFF.  
 
21.  Finally, a universal service obligation policy has been formulated to accelerate the 
expansion of services in rural areas.6 Government regulation 28/2005 allows retaining 0.75% of 
telecommunication companies’ revenues for this purpose. Tendering open to all operators in 
Indonesia has been conducted for performance-based contracts for 11 geographical blocks, 
with the required monthly subsidy as the main bid parameter. In addition, Indonesia is likely to 
witness significant investment in telecom towers. This is another segment that IIFF should look 
out for, although the financing requirements of these projects would largely be in the realm of 
vendor and equipment financing, which is already catered to by existing financial arrangements. 
 
3.  Toll Roads 
 
22.  Road law 38/2004 and the subsequent government regulation 15/2005 on toll roads 
unbundled the sector by (i) ending the monopoly of the main SOE, Jasa Marga, in toll road 
development; (ii) allowing private investors to bid for new toll road concessions in competition 
with Jasa Marga; (iii) separating the regulatory functions from Jasa Marga; and (iv) establishing 
a new regulatory and contracting body, BPJT. Decree 374/2005 of the Ministry of Public Works 
stipulated that the toll road tariffs should be set through a tendering process. At the same time, 
tariffs for existing toll roads were raised by 15–50% to ensure financial sustainability of toll road 
operation. Road law 38/2004 will be complemented by the new Law on Road Traffic and 
Transportation, already drafted by the Ministry of Transportation and submitted to Parliament, 
which  provides  opportunities  for  private  sector  participation  in  transport  services,  transport 
infrastructure such as bus terminals and parking, and support services like vehicle inspection.  
 
23.  BPJT has been active in implementing the Government’s toll road program. Selection of 
private sector sponsors has been undertaken for several batches totaling 28 projects, and 
concession agreements have been signed for 22 of them. There is interest in private sector 
financing in such areas as around Surabaya and the Jakarta outer ring road under a better set 
                                                 
6  In the telecommunications sector, PSO is generally referred to as universal service obligation.

11 
of rules. In both these cases, there is a history of past tendering and suggested repackaging of 
toll roads. IIFF could facilitate the private sector and local government in moving ahead with 
innovative proposals. IIFF could also assist by offering independent expert assistance that 
would enable the state-owned toll road operator Jasa Marga to expand its role in some new toll 
roads. IIFF could raise funds for private investment into existing and new toll roads, bridges, and 
port access roads. Another immediate role for the IIFF is to restructure the model Concession 
Agreement, which needs basic amendments in the banker’s clause and land acquisition-related 
clauses, among others. 
 
4.  Ports 
 
24.  The ports sector will be opening up gradually in the next 3 years, following concrete 
efforts in this direction by the Government and enactment of the Shipping Law in April 2008. 
The unwillingness of the PELINDOs (the state-port operators) to concede monopoly status to 
private operators so far has been one of the root causes of problems in this sector. Rationalizing 
port tariffs, improving port productivity, and creating linkage infrastructure for power generation 
are critical points to be addressed. IIFF could support regional governments in preparing leasing 
contracts for example, pending the appropriate regulatory frameworks’ being put in place.  
 
5.  Urban Water Supply 
 
25.  Water  Resources  Law  7/2004  and  government  regulation  16/2005  on  water  supply 
established the legal framework for PSP by clarifying its forms,7 ending the monopolies of 
regional water supply enterprises (PDAMs), eliminating the need for local parliament approval of 
water tariff increases, and calling for the establishment of the National Water Supply System 
Development  Supporting  Agency.  This  agency  is  an  advisory  body  whose  responsibilities 
include helping formulate sector policy and strategy, setting operational standards for water 
supply,  setting  and  evaluating  service  standards  and  performance  of  PDAMs,  making 
recommendations on involving cooperatives and the private sector in water supply, and settling 
disputes. The two-pronged strategy relies on PDAMs and private concessionaires for expanding 
water supply and sanitation in urban areas. The legal framework has been completed through 
Ministry of Public Works regulations on water supply provision (with detailed guidelines for 
PDAMs and private sector operators) and solid waste management. A key issue in the water 
sector  is  the  relative  lack  of  success  of  major  concession  contracts  (e.g.,  Jakarta’s  two 
contracts, which were subject to substantial political interference under a previous government). 
Nevertheless, the success of some regional water management contracts (e.g., in Tangerang) 
raises potential for PPPs in the water sector. The reduced risks associated with management 
contracts (secured by local governments) suggest a basis for progress toward private sector 
financing. Full concessions are not likely to occur in the medium term, however.   
 
6.  Airports  
 
26.  In the airport sector, the recently approved aviation bill and subsequent creation of an 
independent regulator are expected to create a level playing field for the industry players and 
result in private investment. Past attempts at privatization (e.g., that of Jakarta’s Soekarno-Hatta 
airport) were not successful but indicate a willingness to move and transact. IIFF could advise 
on privatizing selected airports. Currently, 17 projects are lined up in the sector with a combined 
proposed investment outlay of about $3.2 billion. The Government is currently focusing on some 
of these projects, including the Medan Airport, the airport in Makassar, and the New Lombok 
Airport. 
                                                 
7  PSP can take the form of a cooperation agreement with the PDAM concerned or a license granted by the relevant 
local government.

12 
7.  Railways 
 
27.  The railway sector is not prominent in the country, but it gains in importance when 
viewed as a linkage sector to transport resources like coal from the regions of Indonesia (e.g., in 
Kalimantan and Sumatra). Parliament’s passage of law 23/2007 on railways has removed the 
monopoly of the state-owned Indonesian Railway Corporation and established the framework 
for PSP both in developing basic infrastructure and operating rolling stock. The Ministry of 
Transport has drafted four government regulations for the new law that elaborate on, among 
other things, the roles of central and local governments and selection of private sector partners. 
For the railway revitalization program for 2008–2010 that covers Java and North Sumatra, 
where about 4,000 kilometers of railways are still in operation, the Government has allocated 
Rp19 trillion ($2.1 billion) to Indonesian Railway Corporation for a planned joint venture with 
private companies to transport cement, coal, and shipping containers in Sumatra, and as the 
start-up capital for a new subsidiary that will double the capacity of the commuter rail service in 
Jakarta and its environs.  
 
8.  Natural Gas 
 
28.  Given the country’s large reserves, natural gas can play a much more important role 
domestically. Presidential Decree 5/2006 on National Energy Policy calls for a minimum 30% 
share for natural gas in Indonesia’s energy mix by 2025, compared to less than 20% for oil. To 
move toward this target, an oil and gas sector blueprint has been prepared and a master plan 
for the natural gas pipeline network already completed. The new law 30/2007 on energy and the 
related government regulations on energy conservation, renewable energy, and energy supply 
and utilization are all aimed to promote greater PSP. Indonesia’s natural gas sector should also 
be  viewed  from  a  linkage  perspective  and  not  a  resource  perspective,  with  a  focus  on 
developing  transmission  and  distribution  pipelines.  The  successful  private  sector  funding 
obtained by PT Perusahaan Gas Negara (Persero) [PGN] in the gas sales and purchase 
agreement (between PGN subsidiary TBK and Conoco Phillips in Jakarta, 9 August 2004) and 
more recent funding achievements by PGN show just how well the SOE reform process and 
private sector funding can fit together. The gas transport portion of the former Pertamina assets 
was transformed into the entity that is now PGN. The issues in this sector are linked to the 
backward and forward integration of businesses as a result of regulation related to unbundling.  
 
29.  There is good potential for IIFF to target upcoming projects in this sector, such as South 
Sumatra West Java Pagardewa-Labuhan Maringgai, West Java Distribution Expansion, the 
liquefied natural gas (LNG) receiving terminal in East Java, Mini LNG Transportation project, 
integrated coal-based methane development with pipeline transmission, and the compressed 
natural gas Pondok UNGU pilot project. 
 
9.  Subnational Level 
 
30.  At the subnational level, fund availability is not a matter of concern. What is an issue is 
the  management  and  use  of  these  funds.  IIFF  can  become  actively  involved  in  project 
preparation and development at a subnational level to prepare bankable projects. A few pilot 
projects at subnational level could create a demonstration effect to induce competition among 
subnational governments to optimally use the funding for critical infrastructure projects in their 
regions, thereby improving efficiency and providing a regional impetus to the IIFF. 
 
31.  Various sectors are at different stages of evolution. IIFF will need to articulate a strategy 
unique to every sector. Whereas some sectors will be potential candidates for funding, others 
will have to be targeted for project preparation and allied fee-based services. Appendix 12

13 
provides a potential list of PPP projects that IIFF could target, both for investment as well as 
project development advisory services. 
 
G.  ADB Operational Strategy for Infrastructure Development in Indonesia 
 
32.  Partnership  Focus  on  Infrastructure  Development.  ADB’s  country  strategy 
partnership 2006–20098 is focused on improving the quantity and quality of both physical and 
social  infrastructure  by  effectively  using  public,  external,  and  private  sector  resources  and 
thereby  accelerating  growth,  job  creation,  and  poverty  reduction.  Policy,  institutional,  and 
regulatory reforms are considered vital to improving governance and enhancing public and 
private investor confidence in undertaking infrastructure investments. 
 
33.  Complementary Programs. ADB has been providing a series of Development Policy 
Support Programs,9 the fourth of which was approved in December 2008. These programs, 
formulated in conjunction with the World Bank, focused on improving macroeconomic stability, 
the  investment  climate,  public  financial  management,  and  public  service  delivery.  Closely 
related to these objectives has been ADB support for capital market development10 to improve 
the operation and regulation of Indonesia’s nonbank financial markets. Concurrently, ADB has 
supported the Infrastructure Reform Sector Development Program Cluster (footnote 1), which 
outlined a comprehensive set of sector reforms required over 2005–2010. In addition, this 
cluster established a project development facility (PDF) to provide the TA needed to develop 
new infrastructure projects (Appendix 12). The cluster also supported a model infrastructure 
program to illustrate the use of modern project preparation and bidding approaches to efficiently 
reach financial closures. Paragraph 16 provides a brief description of the progress made and 
initiatives undertaken by the Government for developing infrastructure in Indonesia with support 
under IRSDP. In addition, ADB recently approved a loan of up to $300 million to Bank Mandiri, 
of which $75 million is to be funded by ADB (A Loan) and $225 million is to be funded by 
commercial banks (B Loan) under participation agreements between ADB and such banks. This 
intervention is designed to support the Government’s strategy of encouraging private sector 
participation in infrastructure development, given the limited availability of public sector financing. 
 
34.  Centralized Public–Private Partnership Unit and PDF. The IRSDP is strengthening 
the key institutions dealing with infrastructure development in Indonesia. At the national level, 
the ability of the interministerial KKPPI has been strengthened through TA (footnote 3) to fulfill 
its role in formulating infrastructure strategies and policies, coordinating and supervising the 
implementation of these strategies and policies by the line ministries and local governments, 
formulating policies for infrastructure services, and solving problems that impede infrastructure 
development in regard to particular PPP projects. The PDF under the TA (footnote 1) has been 
designed  to  remove  one  of  the  most  critical  constraints  currently  impeding  infrastructure 
development, namely, the lack of adequate project preparation; adopt an open and transparent 
bidding process; and execute project transactions up to the stage of financial closure. It also

assists in overall PPP project promotion and related capacity building at the central and local

35.  IIFF as an Institutional Response. This infrastructure cluster was a response to the 
reduced effectiveness in continuing the development and financing of infrastructure projects 
through government national line ministries and SOEs in cooperation with the private sector. 
The  decentralization  of  many  infrastructure  activities  to  regional  and  local  governments, 
together with the outmoded national regulatory approaches, had meant that these projects 
simply  could  not  be  formulated  and  financed  in  a  satisfactory  manner.  While  efforts  are 
continuing to reform the regulatory framework in conjunction with model projects and TA, an 
institutional focus now needs to be developed to catalyze PPP infrastructure projects—and 
especially  those  sponsored  at  the  regional  and  local  government  levels.  The  proposal  to 
establish IIFF is an essential part of the Government’s reform agenda and an outcome of 
IRSDP to address the key bottlenecks that currently constrain investment in infrastructure. The 
Government requested World Bank and ADB to help prepare a strategy for IIFF, to participate in 
IIFF’s equity capital, and to provide a sovereign loan to the Government for its subordinated 
debt component in IIFF. 
 
H.  Lessons 
 
36.  The  proposed  investment  is  benchmarked  against  two  existing  investment  finance 
institutions:  Infrastructure  Leasing  &  Financial  Services  Limited  (IL&FS)  and  Infrastructure 
Development Finance Company Limited (IDFC), both in India.11 The choice of these companies 
has been driven by the need to identify benchmarks that operate in a developing country with 
significant government presence in infrastructure and where successful operations have been 
achieved. Also, both IL&FS and IDFC are nonbanking finance companies, like the proposed 
IIFF, rather than banks.  
 
37.  IL&FS and IDFC involved the Government of India as one of the initial promoters, but 
both these entities operated on the basis of management principles associated with the private 
sector. Thus, considered together, IL&FS and IDFC cover a significant part of the potential 
positioning and growth strategy options available to IIFF. 
 
38.  IDFC was set up in 1997, jointly by the Government of India (20% stake in the initial 
equity capital of Rs10 billion), Industrial Development Bank of India (5%), Reserve Bank of India 
(15%),12 various  Indian  banks  and  financial  institutions  (25%),  plus  foreign  and multilateral 
institutions including ADB (35%). At incorporation, the Government of India also supported IDFC 
by providing subordinated debt of Rs6 billion with a tenor of 15 years. This was subsequently 
increased to Rs6.5 billion (about $160 million at current exchange rates) and the tenor extended 
to 50 years. IDFC thus started operations with a strong capital base of Rs16 billion ($400 million 
at current rates). Following the initial public offering (IPO) in 2005, IDFC was listed on stock 
exchanges and the holding of the Government of India (including Industrial Development Bank 
of India) declined to 26.4 %. Currently, the Government of India’s equity holding in IDFC is 
about 22%. Fee-based income comprised 7% of total income for 2007. Cumulative loans to 
infrastructure rose from $106 million in 1998 to $3 billion as of March 2007. 
 
                                                 
11 ADB. 1993. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan to India 
for Infrastructure Leasing and Financial Services Limited. Manila (Loan 1282-IND); and ADB. 1997. Report and 
Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on Equity Investment in the Infrastructure Development 
Finance Company Limited (India, Investment No. 7138). Manila. 
12 The Reserve Bank of India stake was subsequently transferred to the Government of India.

15 
39.  IDFC was established with a paid-up capital of $274 million, which remained mostly 
unused in the first few years of operations as IDFC needed a lead time to build up its business. 
In IIFF, the paid-up capital will be subscribed gradually over a period of up to 5 years and in 
tranches depending on the needs of the business. This will minimize the investment risk and 
utilize the equity funding more efficiently. 
 
40.  IL&FS was set up in 1987 by the Central Bank of India, Housing Development Finance 
Corporation Limited, and Unit Trust of India. Over the last 20 years, IL&FS has welcomed 
several  new  shareholders,  including  Orix  Corporation  (Japan),  State  Bank  of  India,  Life 
Insurance Corporation of India, and Abu Dhabi Investment Authority. Nevertheless, it has not 
gone public (although several of its subsidiary and associated companies have been listed). The 
share capital as of March 2006 was $24 million while reserves and surpluses amounted to $159 
million. Total assets as of March 2006 were $1.5 billion. IL&FS follows a strategy of actively 
leveraging  its  connection  with  the  Government  to  get  involved  in  the  project  development 
process at an early stage, often investing its own funds to support project development activities. 
 
41.  The operations of IDFC and IL&FS have important implications for IIFF’s institutional 
positioning and strategy. Both IL&FS and IDFC have clearly adopted roles that extend beyond 
merely providing debt funding for infrastructure projects. This indicates that success in the 
infrastructure  financing  space  requires  a  positioning  that  extends  beyond  pure  lending  to 
encompass other functions related to project preparation and capital market operations. Fee-
based income contributes significantly to the profitability of both companies. It is clear that as 
the policy and regulatory framework for PPP projects in infrastructure falls into place and more 
bankable projects emerge, competition in interest-based products is bound to intensify. Other 
banks and financial institutions will seek funding opportunities in the infrastructure space that 
they  earlier  considered  too  risky.  As  interest  spreads  narrow  due  to  this  increase  in 
competition—and  especially  from  banks  with  their  inherent  advantage  in  terms  of  cost  of 
funds—generating fee income becomes critical to maintain profitability. 
 
42.  Both companies have leveraged their expertise and credibility relating to infrastructure 
projects to generate fee-based income from asset management and advisory services. Both 
IL&FS and IDFC are trusted by the private sector players for their commercial orientation. At the 
same time, they enjoy privileged relationships with the government. This element of positioning 
allows  both  companies  to  bring  together  various  stakeholders  required  for  the  successful 
implementation of a PPP project.  
 
43.  A key lesson from the above case studies is that IIFF will need to take equity stakes in 
infrastructure players and projects on a selective basis. Both IL&FS and IDFC have made equity 
investments in a variety of companies, although IL&FS has been more aggressive on this count. 
This helps to build credibility for projects and ensure their financial closure. Moreover, it allows 
the company to take higher levels of risk in projects that it understands well by virtue of its 
involvement in project development processes and thus to generate higher returns than is 
possible from pure lending activities. 
 
44.  Both model entities have successfully broadened their shareholder bases over time. The 
implication for IIFF is that a large capital base is necessary to scale up operations to a level that 
is significant. Given the large investment requirements in infrastructure, a low capital base 
would constrain IIFF’s ability to take on exposures to large projects. 
 
45.  A clear requirement for success in infrastructure financing is the ability to form and 
nurture relationships with a wide range of stakeholders. Both IDFC and IL&FS have adopted a 
collaborative approach, entering into relationships and alliances even with competitors.

16 
 
46.  It is clear that IIFF has to play a proactive role that will extend to actively supporting 
policy reforms (as does IDFC) as well as involving itself in project development. IL&FS has been 
far more aggressive in committing resources to project development than IDFC. The need for 
such positioning is underlined by the fact that IDFC has recently emulated IL&FS by setting up 
the IDFC Projects Ltd. 
 
47.  When IDFC was created in 1998, Indian infrastructure sectors were also facing problems 
with lack of bankable projects. A question at that time was whether IDFC should be created only 
after the success of reform and project preparation initiatives. IDFC was created in an early 
stage,  and  it  has  proven  successful  in  the  Indian  context.  Learning  from  this  experience, 
Indonesia has indicated it also wishes to operate on a number of parallel tracks, such as to have 
reforms and project preparation initiatives running in parallel to creation of IIFF. 
 
III.  INDONESIAN INFRASTRUCTURE FINANCING FACILITY COMPANY 
A.  Mission and Strategy of the Indonesian Infrastructure Financing Facility Company 
48.  Increasing the flow of private investment into infrastructure projects to a level that is six 
to seven times the current average level is a major challenge facing Indonesia. This challenge is 
further exacerbated by the lack of long-tenor financing in Indonesia. It is in response to this 
challenge that an institutional response named IIFF was conceived in 2007.   
 
49.  IIFF will finance commercially viable infrastructure projects in Indonesia. IIFF’s exposure 
to infrastructure projects that are solely developed by the public sector and SOEs will be limited 
to a maximum of 20% of its overall lending portfolio. To help finance these projects, IIFF will 
seek to arrange cofinancing from pension funds, insurance companies, institutions, commercial 
banks, and other acceptable sources that can provide long-term sources of finance.  
 
50.  IIFF will endeavor to develop capabilities in structuring projects that will attract private 
sector investment. It will seek to assist both the Government in its policy advisory role and the 
private sector in enhancing the commercial viability of projects through bankable contractual 
arrangements that reflect appropriate risk sharing. IIFF will seek to build a capacity to operate 
as a domestic think tank on infrastructure. It is expected to emerge as a national repository of 
experience and skills related to PPP projects in infrastructure. A basic objective of IIFF is to 
bridge systemic gaps while not duplicating roles already discharged by other entities. In the 
financial sector, for instance, IIFF will endeavor to profile itself as an entity creating a new set of 
financing opportunities hitherto not existing rather than as competing with existing financial 
institutions. The project development roles envisaged for IIFF and the one established under the 
IRSDP are independent of each other and no overlaps are envisaged. 
 
51.  IIFF’s positioning is based on its vision, which in turn recognizes the existing gaps and 
opportunities with regard to private funding of infrastructure in Indonesia and the critical success 
factors  identified  from  the  development  of  those  infrastructure  finance  entities  chosen  as 
benchmarks for IIFF. The four key elements of IIFF’s positioning—funds, skills, credibility, and 
relationships—are described below.

for IIFF will be to act as a catalyst for initiatives both by its founding promoters and by new 
parties that bring in funding and expertise.
