B.  Incorporation of PT Sarana Multi Infrastruktur and the Indonesian Infrastructure 
Financing Facility Company   
 
56.  Government Regulation No. 66/2007 provides for state equity participation in a fully 
government-owned holding company, and PTSMI will be formed for this purpose. PTSMI will 
then invest in the equity capital of IIFF. The chief executive officer for PTSMI has been selected. 
Nominations to PTSMI’s board of directors (BOD) and board of commissioners (BOC) was

20 
approved  by  the  minister  of  finance  in  February  2009.  The  BOC    has  three  members. 
Consequent to the establishment of PTSMI on 26 February 2009, the 2007 budgetary allocation 
of Rp1 trillion provided under Government Regulation 66/2007, as amended by Government 
Regulation 75/2008, has now been deposited in PTSMI's account. 
 
57.  IIFF has been conceptualized as a nonbanking financial institution incorporated as a 
limited liability company, and it is to have a target fund base of about $1 billion within 5 years 
from commencing operations. To support this asset base, IIFF will be capitalized by up to $200 
million from equity, up to $200 million from subordinated debt, and up to $550 million being debt 
from the market. The amendment to the Presidential Decree 61/1988 on finance companies 
which is required for incorporation of IIFF has been submitted by MOF to the state secretary 
and  is  expected  to  be  approved  by  the  President  of  Indonesia  by  April  2009.  The 
implementation regulation for the above amendment to the Presidential Decree 61/1988 has 
been drafted and is proposed to be issued shortly after such amendment is issued. IIFF’s 
business operations will be subject to MOF and Bapepam-LK, the Capital Market and Financial 
Institution Supervisory Agency.  
 
C.  Funding Strategy 
   
1.  Capital Structure 
 
    a.  Shareholding Structure 
 
58.  The initial paid up capital of IIFF is proposed to be approximately $10 million in rupiah 
equivalent, and IIFF is projected to have paid-up capital of up to $200 million by year 5 when the 
business has reached a more mature stage. At least five shareholders are proposed to be 
founding shareholders of IIFF.13 These shareholders comprise PTSMI and international financial 
institutions (ADB, IFC, and DEG/KfW). These shareholders propose to subscribe to the share 
capital of IIFF, as shown in Table 3. The founding shareholder group is actively seeking further 
participation from third parties for an additional 15% of equity. In the event that appetite for the 
15% of shares is insufficient PTSMI will subscribe for up to 45% of the total shares, comprising 
a core equity of 30% and additional equity of up to 15% representing the portion of shares not 
taken up by further investors. However, in no event will PTSMI (or any other subdivision or 
agency of the Government) acquire voting rights greater than those represented by a holding of 
30% of IIFF's ordinary shares. Furthermore, in no event will PTSMI or any other agency or 
subdivision of the Government contribute more than 50% of IIFF's total share capital.14 In the

No. 66/2007, which provides for state equity participation through a fully government-owned

D.  Organization and Management  
 
1.  Organizational Structure  
 
63.  IIFF will be managed, as are all Indonesian limited liability companies, by a BOC and a 
BOD. The BOC represents the shareholders while the BOD, which includes the chief executive 
officer (CEO) or president director, is responsible for day-to-day operations. ADB will seek 
representation  on  the  IIFF’s  BOC,  which  will  allocate  its  seats  based  upon  relative 
shareholdings. IIFF’s institutional development, detailing organization structure, systems, and 
operational processes, will be carried out by CRISIL Risk and Infrastructure Solutions Limited, 
which is engaged in the second phase of its consulting assignment. The key aspects of IIFF’s 
proposed organization structure and staffing (which will continue to be developed) are set out in 
Appendix 8. A critical success factor for IIFF will be the quality of its human resources and 
leadership. The president director will play a crucial role, having a mandate to manage the 
operations of  a  start-up  entity  and  quickly  demonstrate  success  as  measured by  financial 
closure of infrastructure projects. The CEO is expected to be an experienced executive with a 
good track record. An international executive search firm has been engaged by IFC to select the 
CEO. A short list of potential candidates has been submitted to the prospective shareholders. It 
includes some of the most prominent bankers and infrastructure practitioners in the market. 
Final selection is expected by April 2009.  
 
  2.  Risk Management 
 
64.  ADB will ensure that appropriate risk management processes will be established within 
IIFF. The risk management processes are described in Appendix 9.

23 
 
3.  Corporate Governance 
 
65.  IIFF will be required to adopt the best corporate governance practices, as proposed in 
appendix 10, which at minimum comply with Indonesian laws and regulations. IIFF will be 
required to adopt the standard codes of good corporate governance prepared by the National 
Committee on Governance and the Forum for Corporate Governance in Indonesia, even though 
these are not mandatory in nature. The aim is to go beyond the standard codes and to adopt 
certain specific elements of corporate governance that are important in the context of IIFF’s 
operations. The proposed corporate governance structure for IIFF is outlined in Appendix 10, 
which  includes  proposals  to  provide  firewalls  between  functions  with  potential  conflicts  of 
interest and to develop a comprehensive policy for the composition and functioning of the credit 
committee. IIFF will be required to adopt appropriate operational procedures to avoid conflicts of 
interest during project identification, evaluation, or development and to ensure that no employee 
involved in the project finance function simultaneously works on policy advisory or project 
development mandates. Appendix 10 also provides for formulating well-defined policies for 
IIFF’s functioning, including policies on treasury operations. 
 
 
IV.  THE PROPOSED LOAN AND EQUITY INVESTMENT IN THE INDONESIAN 
INFRASTRUCTURE FINANCING FACILITY COMPANY 
 
A.  Description and Main Terms of Equity and Loan 
 
  1.  Equity Investment 
 
66.  ADB proposes to make an equity investment in the amount of the lesser of (i) $40 
million (in rupiah equivalent) and (ii) 20% of IIFF’s equity capital. ADB will ensure that it is not 
the  largest  single  investor.  ADB’s  equity  investment  will  be  governed  by  the  terms  of  a 
subscription agreement, a shareholders’ agreement among all founding shareholders of IIFF, 
and IIFF’s Memorandum and Articles of Association. The terms of each of these documents 
remain at this point to be negotiated among the founding shareholders. 
 
67.  ADB  will  ensure  that  the  shareholders’  agreement  reflects  a  general  intent  of  the 
founding shareholders and the company for IIFF to list its shares within 10 years after initial 
subscription. ADB may consider divesting its shares at that time. As with its earlier investment in 
IDFC, however, ADB envisages this investment as a long-term commitment to the development 
of infrastructure financings in Indonesia and will not seek in the shareholders’ agreement to 
obtain rights to an early exit. The terms of the shareholders’ agreement will permit ADB’s 
shareholding to be diluted (without further liability) in the event that, after ADB has fully paid in 
its  maximum  committed  amount,  further  calls  on  shareholder  capital  are  made.  MOF  has 
developed a business plan for PTSMI that indicates how PTSMI will operate.  
 
2.  Loan 
  
68.  A  loan  of  $100  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources  will  be  provided  to 
Indonesia for relending to PTSMI. The loan will be provided under ADB’s London interbank 
offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility. The loan will have a 25-year term and include a 
grace period of 5 years, an interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s LIBOR-based 
lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per annum, and such other terms and conditions

24 
as set forth in the draft loan agreement.16 Indonesia will relend the full amount of the ADB loan 
to PTSMI in rupiah at ADB's lending terms to the Borrower plus other costs to be determined by 
the  Borrower.  PTSMI  will,  in  turn,  under  the  terms  of  the  subsidiary  loan  agreement  with 
Indonesia, lend all such disbursed amounts in their entirety to IIFF as subordinated debt on 
terms to be mutually agreed. PTSMI will relend the subordinated debt to IIFF on a tenor of up to 
25 years. In addition, the Government has made a budgetary provision of Rp1 trillion as its 
contribution toward the initial establishment and further capital needs of IIFF. The entirety of this 
provision has now been deposited into PTSMI's account (para. 56) and will used exclusively for 
funding IIFF’s equity as its capital base expands. Pending capital calls by IIFF, the funds held in 
this account may be lent or invested, as appropriate.  
 
B.  Justification for the Proposed Investments 
 
69.  IIFF  provides  an  opportunity  for ADB  to  leverage  certain  of  its  available  resources 
allocated to Indonesia, where infrastructure shortages are critical and national government 
funds are limited. The approach is based upon ADB’s successful partnership in developing the 
IDFC in India that was intended to be a model for ADB’s other developing member countries, 
such as Indonesia, who are looking for institutional arrangements to stimulate infrastructure 
sector reform, private sector participation in infrastructure finance, and domestic debt market 
development. IIFF will directly address the needs for infrastructure expertise in developing 
infrastructure,  particularly  at  the  local  government  level.  IIFF  will  then  provide  the  needed 
longer-term financing to both public and private parties for the development of commercially 
viable infrastructure projects. 
 
70.  The proposed investments will promote best practices, in risk management, safeguards 
and corporate governance. The participation of multilateral agencies such as ADB, World Bank 
and  IFC  as  shareholders  will  enable  the  adoption  from  IIFF’s  inception  of  adequate  risk 
management systems, corporate governance and safeguards policies that will be crucial in 
promoting sound lending in infrastructure. ADB, IFC and the WB will be represented in the 
Board of Commissioners and various committees and will ensure that these best practices are 
maintained throughout IIFF’s operations. 
 
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
1.  Project Management  
 
71.  MOF’s Directorate General of State Assets Management will be the Executing Agency 
for the Project and responsible for the overall supervision and execution of the Project. The 
Government  will  manage  its  investment  in  IIFF  through  PTSMI.  Though  PTSMI  is 
conceptualized as a shell company to channel and manage the Government’s investment in 
IIFF, it will still have a two-tier board structure as is necessary for locally registered companies. 
The Board of Directors shall be responsible for the day to day management of the Company 
and the Board of Commissioners shall be responsible for providing oversight function. ADB will 
prefer to have two seats on the IIFF BOC and plans to designate nominee directors for its 
allocated directorships. 
 
                                                 
16 The World Bank loan is proposed for 24.5 years at LIBOR + 75 basis points with no levy of commitment charges.

25 
2.  Period of Utilization 
 
72.  The utilization period for the loan is from 1 April 2009 to 31 December 2013. Similarly, it 
is envisaged that ADB’s equity investment will not be available for contribution under the terms 
of the shareholders’ agreement before 1 April 2009 and after 31 December 2013.  
 
3.  Procurement and Disbursement  
 
73.  The project loan will be released upon satisfaction of conditions precedent for initial 
disbursement and based on the Government’s investment need in PTSMI. The loan proceeds 
will  be  used  by  the  Government  for  relending  to  IIFF  as  subordinated  debt  through  the 
government holding company PTSMI based on requests for disbursement made  from  time  to 
time by IIFF. The equity investment will be released in tranches over a period of 5 years until 
December 2013 against calls made by IIFF for its budgeted operating expenses and defined 
loans. All goods financed under the project loan will be procured in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). The Government will cause IIFF 
to  ensure  that  the  goods  to  be  financed  under  the  Loan  proceeds  shall  be  procured  in 
accordance  with  established  private  sector  or  commercial  practices  acceptable  to  ADB, 
purchased at a reasonable price, taken into account also relevant factors such as time of 
delivery, efficiency and reliability of the goods, and their suitability for the relevant infrastructure 
projects. 
 
4.  Anticorruption  
 
74.  The borrower was advised of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) 
and Combating Money Laundering and the Financing of Terrorism Policy (2003). Consistent 
with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and transparency, ADB will require the 
borrower and IIFF to institute, maintain, and comply with internal procedures and controls 
following international best practice standards for the purpose of preventing corruption or money 
laundering activities or the financing of terrorism and to covenant with ADB to refrain from 
engaging in such activities. The investment documentation between ADB and IIFF will further 
allow  ADB  to  investigate  any  violation  or  potential  violation  of  these  undertakings.  The 
Government has considerably strengthened its anticorruption efforts in the past few years. 
Procurement reforms have been under way for some time, resulting in competitive and relatively 
transparent selection of bidders. The private sector participation regulatory framework, adopted 
as part of the IRSDP, sets out clear guidelines for selecting private sponsors. The KKPPI is 
tasked with ensuring that the bidding processes—paras. 16 (ii) and 34—are fair and transparent. 
Furthermore, the President of Indonesia has considerably enhanced the profile and visibility of 
the Anti-Corruption Commission and other law enforcement agencies to deal effectively with 
corruption. These steps are already having an impact. 
 
75.  Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and transparency, 
ADB reserves the right to review and examine any alleged corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or 
coercive practices relating to the subprojects under the facility. IIFF will be required to adopt the 
best corporate governance practices in accordance with its positioning whereby it needs to be 
seen as a credible institution in the eyes of all stakeholders. Accordingly, the focus is to go 
beyond the standard codes, and ADB will cause specific elements of corporate governance to 
be adopted that are important in the context of IIFF’s operations. The teams involved in policy 
reform and project development will be entirely discrete and separated from the core team 
looking at project finance operations (para. 3 B (ii), Appendix 10 on corporate governance). The 
firewall between functions will be rigorously implemented by IIFF’s president director. ADB will 
ensure—as  a  condition  for  its  subsequent  subscription  and  payment—that  procedures  are

26 
prepared and implemented that provide for all of these matters. A written code of ethical 
conduct applicable to all commissioners, directors, and other employees will be prepared and 
made  available  to  all  commissioners,  employees,  and  directors  of  IIFF.  This  code  will  be 
displayed  on  IIFF’s  website.  The  details  of  any  related-party  transactions  will  be  clearly 
disclosed in annual reporting. The shareholders’ agreement will require IIFF regularly to report 
in its annual reports on the following aspects: (i) shareholding by employees or members of the 
BOD  and  BOC;  (ii)  accounting  principles  and  prudential  norms  applied;  (iii)  related-party 
transactions (including subsidiaries and companies controlled by IIFF); (iv) remuneration of 
directors and commissioners; (v) risk management systems adopted; (vi) policies relating to 
personnel, human resource management, project appraisal, and credit sanction; (vii) proceeds 
of any issue of equity; and (viii) relationships with and activities among employees and the wider 
community. These elements of corporate governance are presented in Appendix 10. 
  
5.  Accounting, Auditing, and Reporting  
 
76.  ADB retains the right to audit the use of loan proceeds and to verify the accuracy of the 
Government’s certification for the withdrawal application. The loan will be released based on 
requests for disbursement made by IIFF. Except as ADB may otherwise agree, the Borrower 
shall establish immediately after the Effective Date, a deposit account to be managed by PTSMI 
at a commercial bank acceptable to ADB and to be used solely for the purpose of the Project. 
The deposit account shall be utilized exclusively by PTSMI to transfer the Loan proceeds to IIFF 
within 3 business days of its receipt. The currency of the deposit account shall be in Dollar. The 
amount to be deposited into the deposit account shall be based on the withdrawal application 
submitted by the Borrower, which will be made pursuant to the investment needs of IIFF to be 
evidenced by the certification issued by PTSMI, endorsed by the Borrower and acceptable to 
ADB.  IIFF  will  also  (i)  maintain  accounting, management  information,  and  financial  control 
systems acceptable to ADB; (ii) maintain independent auditors from auditing firms licensed to 
operate in Indonesia and acceptable to ADB and authorize such auditors to submit financial 
statements to ADB at least annually; (iii) provide ADB with financial statements for purposes of 
ADB’s  reporting  in  its  books  the  earnings  on  its  equity  holdings;  and  (iv)  permit  ADB 
representatives access to all sites where its activities are conducted, as well as to its books, 
accounts, and records. The deadline for submitting audited accounts will be 6 months from the 
end of each fiscal year. 
 
D.  Environmental and Social Aspects 
 
77.  The investment has been classified as FI under ADB’s Environment Policy (2002) and 
category C under ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995) and Policy on Indigenous 
Peoples (1998). A draft environment and social management system (ESMS) prepared by ADB 
and endorsed by the proposed Executing Agency has been disclosed on the ADB website. The 
World Bank and IFC have agreed to have a single ESMS document to be adopted by IIFF upon 
incorporation. It is also proposed to support IIFF in building institutional capacity to implement 
the ESMS. Appendix 11 sets out the indicative ESMS guidelines for preparing the ESMS, while 
the detailed draft is included in a supplementary appendix 2.

27 
 
V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Expected Impacts and Outcomes  
 
78.  The Project is expected to support Indonesia's economic growth and poverty reduction. 
The  expected  outcome  will  be  financing  of  commercially  viable  infrastructure  projects  in 
Indonesia and providing structuring development advice to the Government. This will be done 
by providing financial assistance via debt instruments, equity investments, or guarantees. It will 
provide financing to infrastructure projects structured as PPPs or capable of being so structured. 
IIFF will promote project development frameworks that support PPPs. Like ADB, IIFF will wish 
to ensure that it does not crowd out the private sector in providing its financial assistance, and it 
will be careful to diversify its risk across a broad portfolio of Indonesian infrastructure projects. 
Accordingly, ADB will ensure that IIFF limits its net exposure to any project to a maximum 20% 
of project cost. On this basis, IIFF is expected to finance infrastructure projects with aggregate 
project costs of up to $5 billion in the first 5 years of its operations. Enhanced private sector 
participation through PPPs will contribute to containing and eventually reducing Indonesia’s 
fiscal deficit.   
 
B.  Project Benefits and Beneficiaries 
 
79.  On the demand side, the need for infrastructure investment is well established based on 
the current indicators of service coverage and quality, comparison with historical investment 
levels,  and  the  need  to  accelerate  infrastructure  investment  to  sustain  high  growth  and 
economic  expansion  needed  for  poverty  reduction.  The  benefits  to  society  arising  from 
improved  and  more  equitable  access  to  infrastructure  and  the  strong  linkages  between 
economic growth and investment in infrastructure are all well established by global experience. 
These factors taken together represent the demand-side business case for setting up IIFF. 
 
80.  On  the  supply  side,  it  is  clear  that  the  Indonesian  banks  dominating  the  country’s 
financial system are not in a position to provide long-tenor loans for infrastructure projects. 
Moreover, the limited development of domestic capital markets means very few developers of 
infrastructure projects have the option of disintermediation (i.e., directly tapping the financial 
markets for long-tenor debt funding by issuing bonds or other debt instruments). Thus, there is a 
definite need of long-tenor loans for infrastructure projects, and, as such loans are currently not 
available in the Indonesian context, this by itself provides a basis for setting up IIFF. There are 
similar  constraints  in  directly  mobilizing  domestic  savings  for  funding  the  required  equity 
investments  in  infrastructure  projects.  This  would  thus  address  the  current  supply-side 
constraints and facilitate the flow of funds to infrastructure projects in Indonesia. 
 
81.  In addition to needing fund-based products, Indonesia’s financial system at present lacks 
non-fund based credit enhancement and risk management products for PPP projects. Based on 
its established skills in this segment and superior understanding of the risks involved, IIFF will 
easily  address  this  gap  by  offering  such  non-fund  based  products  as  guarantees.  Other 
innovative funding mechanisms will be available through cofinancing, refinancing and take-out 
financing, mezzanine financing, and securitization (for long-term opportunities). IIFF will also 
play a strategic role in project development, helping clients to structure PPP projects to create 
investor interest and establish credibility for their projects.

28 
 
C.  Risks and Safeguards 
 
82.  ADB is conducting a legal and financial due diligence review in relation to the proposed 
investment. This review is ongoing. Documentation of the equity investment is scheduled to 
commence as soon as possible. The main risks described below are regarded as acceptable for 
an investment of this kind. 
 
(i)   Economic and political risks. Looking ahead, the economic outlook includes 
many challenges. Significant adverse effects of the global financial turmoil have 
emerged since September 2008. Government bond yields spiked to 20% by end-
October  2008  as  foreign  investors  tried  to  reduce  exposures  while  market 
liquidity dried up. The Jakarta stock index fell by 30% in October 2008 (by more 
than 50% since the beginning of the year). The rupiah has depreciated by more 
than 30% since September 2008 despite heavy intervention by Bank Indonesia. 
Continued weakness in commodity prices and tighter financing conditions would 
depress exports and investment going forward. However, increased exchange 
rate flexibility, adequate reserve levels, improved export diversity, and declining 
external debt should limit the potential impact of negative external shocks. While 
risks  and  uncertainties  remain,  continued  good  economic  management  will 
ensure the gradual restoration of full macroeconomic stability. Further progress in 
structural reforms and in removing infrastructure investment bottlenecks would 
also help mitigate the impact of global slowdown. 
(ii)   Regulatory and project development risk. Much of the difficulty in financing 
Indonesia’s infrastructure originates from constraints in the policy, regulatory, and 
project development areas. Reform of these constraints is critical to the long-term 
success of IIFF. The complementary programs discussed in paras. 33–34 of the 
text are expected to relieve these constraints. The Government recognizes the 
need  to  continue  the  policy  and  regulatory  reform  process  together  with 
accelerated project development activities. In addition, other projects will become 
bankable  with  IIFF’s  introducing  appropriate  types  of  financing  or  credit 
enhancements.  IIFF  will  also  contribute  directly  to  this  accelerated  process 
through its project development and policy advisory roles. 
(iii)  Commencement risk. As a start-up company, IIFF faces risks associated with 
the  implementation  of  a  business  plan  by  a  company  with  no  preexisting 
business. It further seeks to multiply the existing Indonesian deal flow by a factor 
of five to seven within a space of 5 years. Accordingly, IIFF faces the risks that 
(a) demand for financial assistance and for fee-based services may be lower 
than  projected;  and  (b)  that  implementation  of  the  necessary  policies  and 
procedures, recruitment of staff, and other operational matters may take longer 
than anticipated. In all cases, these risks would impact on IIFF’s business plan 
and, as a result, on the disbursement of ADB’s loan and the contribution of its 
equity. However, the business plan has been prepared in a conservative manner 
and based on a realistic assessment of the potential project pipeline. Moreover, 
the Government is also preparing 10 national-level PPP projects to be available 
for  financing  under  the  PPP  mode.  The  provision  of  fee-based  services  is 
believed to offer considerable revenue buffer in the early years and will assist in 
building up a strong pipeline. Financial losses associated with commencement 
risk  are  mitigated  through  capital  inflows  being  subject  to  call.  Under  this 
structure,  ADB  will  only  be  required  to  subscribe  for  $2  million  of  equity  at 
inception, with future funding calls conditional upon satisfactory establishment of 
IIFF and achievement of certain business milestones.

29 
(iv)  Funding risk. By the time IIFF is established, if further investors’ (i.e. investors 
other than PTSMI, IFC, ADB, and KfW/DEG) participation is less than 15% of the 
total shares in IIFF, PTSMI will subscribe for additional shares to take up that 
portion of the equity not acquired by such investors. It is envisaged that PTSMI’s 
share ownership may exceed 30% if further investors subscribe for anything less 
than a 15% shareholding in IIFF, but its voting rights will in any event be limited 
to 30% and it will be obligated to dilute down to 30% ownership as such further 
investors subscribe for shares. 
(v)  Asset quality risk. IIFF, as a project financier, will be exposed to the credit risk 
of its borrowers. This risk will be mitigated by IIFF’s adopting market-based 
lending systems incorporating a risk management and credit review process 
consistent with best practices in private sector banks and by the recruitment of a 
professional  management  team.  IIFF  will  provide  financial  assistance  using 
project  finance  structures  common  in  the  industry.  These  will,  to  the  extent 
possible, be conditioned on adequate security and other recourse arrangements 
that will mitigate IIFF’s losses in the event that projects are unable to support 
their debt service obligations.  
(vi)   Management risk. The senior management of IIFF is being recruited. IFC has 
engaged an international executive search firm to help select the CEO. Critical 
are the international competitive governance arrangements initiated up front in 
the shareholder agreements and the Government’s commitment to allow fully 
commercial operations based upon internationally accepted standards. In this 
regard, the Government has committed to keep its shareholding such that, both 
directly and indirectly, it will hold around 30% of the subscribed shares of IIFF. 
Highly skilled staff will be required to manage IIFF. Such skills will be sought in 
searches  for  all  senior  management  and  board  appointments.  Competitive 
salaries and benefits will be paid. This risk is mitigated by the commitment of all 
stakeholders to obtain the best candidate on the market. 
(vii)   Risk of conflict of interest. IIFF’s business plan proposes that IIFF offer both 
advisory services to government in relation to the structuring of selected PPP 
projects and financial assistance to those same projects. This strategy, unless 
carefully controlled and managed using informational firewalls that are apparent 
both internally and externally, exposes IIFF and potentially its shareholders to a 
risk of reputational damage. ADB will ensure that IIFF sets up robust information 
firewalls  and  implements  procedures  assuring  that  its  position  vis-à-vis 
co-lenders and government are fully disclosed.  
(viii)   Exit risk. ADB plans to exit from its investment in IIFF via either a private sale to 
a third party or an initial public offering (IPO) of shares—in either case within 
approximately 10 years from the date of its initial investment. Although the stock 
markets in Indonesia have made great progress since the 1990s, they are not as 
developed as are those of other countries in the region. A variety of factors can 
affect the Indonesian financial markets in general and IIFF’s preparation for an 
IPO in particular. In addition, the current financial crisis may result in delaying the 
IPO and make ADB’s investment difficult to manage. This risk can be mitigated 
by identifying and negotiating an exit sale with a third-party buyer.

30 
 
VI.  EXPOSURE LIMITS 
83.  As of 30 September 2008, total approved nonsovereign exposure in Indonesia was 
$140.36 million, excluding the $350 million exposure to the Tangguh LNG Project,17 which was 
classified as a non-developing member country exposure. Actual nonsovereign exposure in 
Indonesia as of 30 September was $65.36 million. The proposed equity investment would be 
ADB’s first equity investment in a nonbank financial institution in Indonesia. The proposed equity 
investment will be within ADB’s industry, group, and country exposure limits for nonsovereign 
operations. Compliance with the single exposure limit, however, can only be determined at the 
time of capital calls.  
 
VII.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
A.  Specific Assurances 
84.  In addition to the standard assurances, the Government and PTSMI have given the 
following assurances, which will be incorporated in the legal documents: 
 
(i)  The Government will, on timely basis, provide counterpart funds required for the 
establishment and operation of PTSMI and IIFF. 
(ii)  The Government will (a) ensure that the Shareholders Agreement provides that 
the entire proceeds of the Loan will be solely used for relending to PTSMI, and 
(b) exercise its voting powers in relation to the Company and all powers of

loan for the purposes described herein.  
(iii)  The  Government  will  ensure  that  PTSMI  will  be  audited  annually  by  an 
independent external auditor. The audited financial statement of PTSMI will be

(v)  The Government and PTSMI will ensure and will cause IIFF to adopt a corporate 
policy  for  environmental  and  social  management  and  establish  an

INFRASTRUCTURE SECTOR BACKGROUND 
 
1.  Indonesia  has  had  mixed  experiences  with  bringing  the  private  sector  into  its 
infrastructure development. The country’s attempts over three decades to seek private sector 
participation can be viewed in four phases: 
(i)  A first attempt at public–private partnerships (PPPs) in the 1980s, with the most 
notable project being an elevated toll road that now forms part of Jakarta’s inner 
ring road and connects to its main port. 
(ii)  The precrisis 1990s with investment bankers lining up to participate in financing 
independent power producers (IPPs) and toll roads, albeit usually under a direct-
appointment, non-tendered model established in the 1980s. 
(iii)  The onset of the financial crisis in mid-1997 and the period thereafter. 
(iv)  The recent past, with 91 cooperation projects being tabled at the Indonesia 
Infrastructure Summit (2005) and the sunrise legislation in Presidential Decree 
67/2005 that provides a framework for private sector participation. 
 
2.  A key point is that to date there has been relatively little experience with competitively 
tendered, project-finance models of infrastructure investment in Indonesia. In project-finance 
models,  it  is  the  revenue  streams  of  the  project,  supported  by  regulatory  and  judicial 
enforcements as per the tendered contract, which secure the income streams. These, then, 
allow  scope  for  private  finance  at  the  resulting  level  of  risk  and  return.  The  Indonesian 
Infrastructure  Financing  Facility  Company  (IIFF)  is  intended  to  facilitate  and  advance  this 
project-finance model. It will build upon work done by Infrastructure Development Financing 
Company  Limited  and  Infrastructure  Leasing  and  Financial  Services  Limited  in  India  and 
financing  structures  in  many  Organisation  for  Economic  Co-operation  and  Development 
countries.  
 
3.  After dabbling with private sector participation in infrastructure during the 1980s, the 
Government recognized the need for large-scale private investment in the power sector during 
the 1990s and embarked on soliciting proposals for independent power projects. By the onset of 
the financial crisis in mid-1997, State Electricity Corporation (PLN) had signed numerous power 
purchase agreements (PPAs) amounting to investments of more the $15 billion. Most of the 
projects included unsolicited proposals and had political as opposed to institutional backing. The 
projects thus embodied major elements of political risk, as became manifest when the exercise 
of presidential powers over tariffs made many such projects financially unviable. In parallel, toll 
road and water supply concessions were also being directly awarded. Because of presidential 
endorsement,  financing  institutions  and  investment  banks  were  falling  over  themselves  to 
participate in the electricity sector while some foreign investors and state banks had become 
keen on toll road investments, given political or “family” support.  
 
4.  This “direct political appointment” model ended abruptly in September 1997 with the 
issue of Presidential Decree 37, which put many public and private infrastructure projects on 
hold. The decree defined three project categories: “allowed to proceed,” “subject to review,” and 
“postponed.” A couple of months later, in November, another Presidential Decree reclassified 
some of the “subject to review” projects to “allowed to proceed.” This decision was in turn 
reversed in January 1998 following the arrival of the International Monetary Fund. Things did not 
run smoothly even for those projects “allowed to proceed.” As the rupiah plunged from Rp2,300 
to the US dollar to as low as Rp17,000, PLN declared that it would pay its independent power 
producer (IPP) obligations at a fixed rate of Rp2,450 to the US dollar and would renegotiate all 
PPAs. This process was substantially completed in mid-2003, with 14 projects continuing on 
renegotiated terms, five agreed for acquisition, and seven closed out. Three projects were taken

Appendix 2  37
to international arbitration, with IPPs winning all, and the execution of one award is still pending. 
The Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency paid out its first-ever expropriation claim ($15 
million) under political risk cover to Enron in 2002, and the United States’ Overseas Private 
Investment Corporation paid out close to $300 million around the same time on one of the 
geothermal projects that had gone to arbitration. The fallout was slightly less dramatic in the toll 
road sector, but with the result that many concession awards are currently in limbo. 
 
5.  The most-recent phase of infrastructure investment, which began with the Indonesia 
Infrastructure Summit in 2005, can be viewed as the fourth and potentially the most reformist of 
all  phases.  If  infrastructure  project  preparations  and  outcomes  begin  to  reflect  ministerial 
statements  at  the  2005  and  2007  summits,  then  there  is  potential  to  establish  credible 
regulatory, financial, and institutional checks in order to enable and catalyze unhindered flow of 
investment into infrastructure.  
 
6.  Presidential Decree 67 is significant legislation in the context of this new situation, as it 
accords the Ministry of Finance (MOF) authority to review and to approve or reject proposals for 
government  support  to  infrastructure  cooperation  projects.  It  specifies  the  objectives  and 
principles of cooperation projects, treatment of unsolicited proposals, tariff-setting principles, 
methods of procurement, and the principles of granting government support. The activities of 
groups such as the Risk Management Unit in the Ministry of Finance, the new independent 
regulatory bodies, and the National Committee for the Acceleration of Infrastructure Provision 
need to be made complementary in nature to reap the full benefits of the institutional structure. 
 
7.  Although, there are different views on what went wrong with the country’s infrastructure 
development, there is general consensus that lack of good governance, inadequate project 
preparation, poor regulatory frameworks, and an absence of regulation and transparent bidding 
procedures hindered the evolution of private sector financing roles and PPPs. Additionally, the 
currency crisis coupled with dollar-denominated financing for most infrastructure projects in the 
precrisis era exacerbated the problem.  
A.  Different Sectors Are at Different Points of Evolution 
8.  The important infrastructure sectors in Indonesia are power, telecommunications, toll 
roads,  ports,  water,  airports,  railways,  natural  gas,  waterways,  and  a  few  projects  being 
implemented by subnational governments. Among these, telecom saw the fastest revival in the 
postcrisis era by virtue of its being attractive to private investors, fundamentally because of the 
secure private underpinning of typical telephone contracts, both fixed line and mobile. The 
successful recent tendering of the 3G frequency has shown Indonesia’s telecommunications 
sector  to  be  capable  of  moving  with  more  advanced  models  of  competitive  behavior  and 
transparent contracting.  
 
9.  The total investment envisaged through 2015 in the identified sectors via projects at 
different  stages  of  development  is  estimated  to  exceed  $75  billion.  Nearly  46%  of  this 
investment (i.e., some $35 billion) is expected to occur in the power sector. This is followed by 
development of toll roads at $22 billion, which makes up 29% of the total, and of railways at $8 
billion (11% of the total). While the pipeline looks impressive and attractive enough to generate 
private sector interest, it will take some time to realize these projects on the ground because 
barely 8% of the projects have either achieved financial closure or are under construction. About 
12% of the projects have formal agreements with project awarding agencies but have not yet 
achieved financial closure, and 63% of these projects are still at the beginning of the project

38  Appendix 2 
development cycle (i.e., either they are being planned or agreements are yet to be signed). 
About 16% of the projects lack information beyond that of the projected investment amount. 
 
10.  The power and toll roads sectors are the only two sectors (along with the ports sector to 
a more limited extent) in which the project pipeline is spread across the various stages of 
development. This signifies a high level of activity toward implementation in these sectors vis-à-
vis the other sectors. The power and toll roads sectors are likely to surge ahead of the others in 
terms  of  increasing  investment  opportunities  and  realization  of  the  current  pipeline.  The 
Government has indicated its heightened priority for increasing power generation through a 
10,000 MW crash program and for toll roads by way of establishing a regulatory (although not 
fully independent) framework. In the other sectors, projects are either still in the planning stages 
or insufficient information is available about them to arrive at conclusions.  
 
B.  Power Sector 
 
11.  The political and economic crisis during 1997 and 1998 resulted in there being almost no 
investment into the power sector during 1998–2004, leaving Indonesia with the lowest installed 
capacity per capita in Asia. The power sector has begun to see modest investments since 2005. 
The demand for electricity is set to rise by 7–9% p.a. through 2010, thus creating a significant 
demand-supply gap. The system suffered from an estimated deficit of 20,000 gigawatt-hours as 
of 2008. 
 
12.  The Government has initiated a program to develop 10,000 MW of coal-fired power 
plants, and PLN has responded by raising $2 billion through international bond sales in 2006 
and 2007 to raise a portion of the financing. The IPP Program targets suburban areas suffering 
from severe power shortage. The Fast Track Program is an accelerated program to develop 
coal-fired power plants in Java (10 plants) and outside Java (30 plants) by 2010. The crash 
program plus other planned power plants through 2015 with a combined capacity of about 
25,000 MW are likely to strengthen generation capacity by about 35,000 MW in the next 7–8 
years.  Considering  the  capital  expenditure  trend,  the  total  investment  required  in  power 
generation alone, according to PLN estimates, would be around $57 billion by 2018. In addition, 
$14 billion needs to be invested into transmission and $12 billion for distribution during the same 
period. Thus, the overall sector investment needs averages out to at least $8 billion per year.  
 
13.  The  issues  in  the  power  sector  revolve  around  PLN,1 the  single  off-taker  in  the 
Indonesian electricity market. Two related issues are the credit risk of PLN and the tariff-setting 
process. The national electricity tariff in Indonesia applies a uniform tariff structure throughout 
the country despite significantly varying costs. It is highly politicized and is established by 
presidential decree. Because of the universal tariff structure,2 PLN is losing money with every 
residential customer to which it connects outside the Java–Bali grid. Given the potentially huge 
number of such consumers, there are limits to cross-subsidization by other consumer categories. 
                                                 
1  PLN has provided the sector with more than 85% of the total installed capacity, while the balance is supplied by

Government’s  designated  corporate  owner  of  PLN;  the  Ministry  of  Energy  and  Mineral  Resources,  which 
formulates energy policy and issues regulations; and the Ministry of Finance (MOF), which is the financial owner of 
PLN. A board of commissioners, acting on behalf of the Government, is responsible for daily oversight of PLN’s 
proceedings. The power sector in Indonesia does not have an independent regulatory authority.

rupiah-denominated tariff.

Appendix 2  39
To exacerbate PLN’s financial woes, the removal of the fuel subsidy in 2005 means that fuel 
costs increased substantially in its diesel-dominated fuel mix. 
 
14.  The process of streamlining the regulatory and policy structure within the power sector 
was set back in December 2004 when the Constitutional Court annulled the Electricity Law 
20/2002 on the grounds that its provisions for unbundling and competition violated the 1945 
Constitution. The annulment has seriously impeded power sector reforms, with potentially far-
reaching consequences for sector efficiency and financial sustainability, as well as investor 
confidence. Nevertheless, we believe there will be leasing and other financing mechanisms to 
enable  private  sector  financing  consistent  with  the  constitutional  requirement  that  the 
Government of Indonesia retain control over the sector. 
 
15.  Efforts are being made to mobilize financing for the power sector, but a clear strategy 
that optimally allocates public finances to leverage private investments is missing.    
 
16.  The Government has initiated a program to develop 10,000 MW of coal-fired power 
plants, and PLN has responded by issuing a $1 billion international bond to raise a portion of the 
financing. It remains questionable, however, whether this expansion can be adequately financed 
by PLN without some form of government assistance. Private investment in the power sector 
has been in a global decline since the 1990s, and it has been almost negligible in Indonesia in 
recent years. If the private sector is to augment critically needed investments, it will be important 
for PLN to develop a few model transactions with a strategy for managing risks that investors 
would view as credible. Several IPP projects have been tendered, but, due to the various 
associated risks deemed unacceptable by investors, these have yet to achieve financial closure. 
There is a clause in the PPA that imposes a penalty on the investor equal to 2% of the project 
cost if the investor fails to achieve financial closure within 1 year of signing the PPA. Many 
investors, therefore, do not sign PPAs until such time as the financing has been tied up (even 
after PLN has awarded projects). 
 
17.  International Finance Corporation is currently working on the Central Java coal-fired 
power plant. The planned capacity of this plant will be 2 x 1,000 MW. The estimated investment 
is $2.5 billion. International Finance Corporation started the feasibility study in April 2008 under 
an advisory services agreement with PLN. The project site will be located in Pemalang, Central 
Java.  Another  model  project  is  the  Pasuruan  Combined  Cycle  Power  Plant.  The  planned 
capacity of this plant is likely to be 1 x 500 MW. The estimated investment is $275 million. A 
decision by PLN is awaited in order to proceed with the prefeasibility study to be funded from a 
project development facility financed by Asian Development Bank. Discussions are ongoing 
between PLN and potential gas suppliers. Apart from the above two model projects, there are 
several IPP projects in the pipeline and 155 IPP licenses have been issued. According to 
estimates, $3 billion worth of IPP projects are at a stage where the PPA agreements have been 
signed but financial closure has not been reached. 
 
C.  Telecommunications Sector 
 
18.  The telecom sector plays an important role in the country’s landscape, because it can 
reduce  regional  disparities  and  act  as  an  important  leveler  in  an  archipelago.  Access  to 
telecommunications services in Indonesia is among the lowest in the region, with only about 
four fixed lines per 100 people, compared to 18–20 fixed lines elsewhere. According to the 
Ministry of Communications and Information Technology, the country’s fixed-line teledensity in 
2006 was just above 6%. Major cities had a teledensity of 40% while this was less than 0.2% in 
rural areas (with 60% of villages having no telephone services). The total mobile telephone

40  Appendix 2 
density was close to 29% while that of the Internet was about 9%. The World Bank estimates 
that  demand  will  continue  to  grow,  teledensity  will  reach  40%  in  2010,  3G  technology 
penetration will be around 13%, while fixed lines and fixed wireless will reach up to 17% and 
36% of households, respectively.  
 
19.  Since February 2005, the Ministry of Communications and Information Technology has 
had oversight powers across the full range of telecommunications and media. It assumed 
primary responsibility for telecommunications sector reform and development, taking in as well 
the  Directorate  General  of  Post  and  Telecommunications  plus  existing  responsibilities  for 
information and communication technology applications, broadcasting, and information services.  
 
20.  The Indonesian Telecommunications Regulatory Body (BRTI), effective from 2004, is the 
regulator  for  the  sector.  BRTI  has  become  increasingly  active,  although  full  regulatory 
independence has not been achieved. BRTI has a telecommunications regulatory committee 
which is chaired by the Directorate General of Post and Telecommunications. 
 
21.  To meet the growing demand for Internet services, the Government has launched the 
ambitious “Palapa Ring” project. The project aims to link Java, Kalimantan, Maluku, Nusa 
Tenggara, Papua, Sulawesi, and Sumatra, plus eight existing network connections or backhauls 
through an estimated total 35,280 kilometers of undersea and 21,870 kilometers of underground 
fiber-optic cable. The Palapa Ring project’s total cost is about $1.5 billion, and it is the only 
model project in the telecommunications sector from the Government’s list of 10 model projects. 
The pipeline also includes the Urban Service Obligation program under the Urban Service 
Obligation Policy.3 This countrywide program of rural telecommunications and informatics aims 
to cover 43,000 villages before the end of 2010. Also in the pipeline is BWA-3GWiMAX, a 
wireless technology project that may be tendered sometime in 2009. 
D.  Toll Roads Sector 
22.  Roads  in  Indonesia  account  for  a  major  share  of  domestic  freight  and  interurban 
passenger land travel, and their coverage and condition are crucial to supporting economic 
growth and social development. The toll road sector comprises the road, freeway, and highway 
network across the length and breadth of the country that operates on a toll basis.  
 
23.  Responsibility  for  national  toll  road  development  and  maintenance  lies  with  the 
Directorate General of Highways in the Ministry of Public Works. There also exists an overlap in 
responsibilities for development and maintenance of road assets between the Ministry of Public 
Works (MPW) and Ministry of Transportation (MOT). Since 2005, the Indonesian Toll Road 
Authority (BPJT)4 has filled the roles of project preparation, contracting out, and regulation for 
the sector. 
 
24.  The total length of national roads that are not toll-based is 34,628 kilometers, and 650 
kilometers of national roads are toll-based. The condition of the subnational road network is 
substantially poorer than that of the national roads (provincial roads are rated 63% good or fair

and district roads 50% good or fair).5 Construction of major intercity expressways and new ring 
roads for major cities will require a significant increase in road investment. Construction of the 
trans-Java  highway  connecting  Jakarta  and  Surabaya  with  about  870  kilometers  of  new 
expressways is estimated to cost $5 billion, of which land acquisition may account for $500 
million.  A  similar  expressway  system  will  be  needed  for  Sumatra.  The  Government  also 
recognizes the need to ensure the continued good condition of the national road network and to 
improve the condition of the subnational network.  
 
25.  Given the  magnitude  of the sector’s investment requirements, the Government has 
responded with a doubling of its investment budget for 2008 for national roads to about $1.8 
billion. That amount covers both investment and maintenance. The MOF considers a road fund 
unacceptable and prefers that financing be provided directly through the regular budget. With 
regard to the tariff policy, a decree issued by the MPW in 2005 enables road tariffs to be set on 
the basis of a bidding process.6 The Government has also attempted to address governance 
issues in the sector by separating the regulatory and operational functions of Jasa Marga, the 
state-owned enterprise (SOE) for toll roads, through Government Regulation 15/2005 on toll 
roads. This regulation provides for the establishment of a new regulatory body (BPJT), ends 
Jasa  Marga’s  monopoly,  and  facilitates  large-scale  private  sector  participation  in  direct 
competition  with  Jasa  Marga.  The  regulation  itself  is  being  reviewed  to  strengthen  BPJT 
institutionally and enhance its independence. 
 
26.  Development of the road network requires extensive land acquisition. Until recently, no 
specific roles for resolving land issues were assigned to relevant ministries or departments, and 
no specific funding was earmarked for this purpose. Also, the existing legal framework entails 
complicated negotiations and lengthy grievance procedures for settling land titles. As a project 
preparatory measure, it is imperative to have the title history and rights for acquired land well 
established. In the absence of that, a road project development is fraught with risk. Where 
concession agreements have been signed, the issue of contract enforceability and project 
structuring can hinder the financial closure of road projects. The implementation of road works is 
often expensive and of low quality, and collusion among contractors is a problem. Performance 
delivery in the construction industry is frequently substandard, and so is the capacity of the 
regional agencies that need to be strengthened in order to enforce contracts diligently.7 
 
27.  Increased project investment is reflected in the planned pipeline of projects that could to 
some  extent  address  the  increasing  demand.  Following  the  formation  of  an  independent 
regulator for the sector and the hosting of Infrastructure Summit 2005, the sector witnessed a 
restart of 32 stalled as well as new toll road projects. Of these 32 toll roads, two are now in 
operation and the balance of projects is in various stages of execution. The total investment 
requirement for these projects is estimated at $10 billion. The MPW has recently prepared a list 
of 11 toll roads that it wants to implement as priorities. The indicative total planned supply of 
roads at the national level will absorb investment in the range of $22 billion in the medium term, 
as the development process of most projects is underway. Thus, it is likely that in the medium to 
long term, the private sector’s contribution to national toll road development may witness a 
significant rise from the current 25% of the 650 kilometers.

E.  Ports Sector 
28.  Indonesia has a large number of ports that are organized under four state corporations 
(PELINDOs). These have a large degree of autonomy and are, in most cases, financially 
self-sufficient. There are also a number of private ports and terminals for bulk cargo (e.g., 
Cilacap and Cigadeng). The current legal framework defines the various categories of ports, 
specifies that management of all general ports is the responsibility of the Government (which 
can delegate it to an SOE), and allows private sector participation only through a cooperation 
agreement  with  an  SOE.  Based  on  this  framework,  the  Government  had  allocated  the 
management and development of 111 ports to four Indonesian port corporations (PELINDOs I–
IV).  The  Law  on  Shipping  was  passed  by  the  Parliament  on  8  April  2008  and  has  been 
submitted to the State Secretariat for enactment. This will change the fundamental structure of 
the  sector  over  the  next  3  years,  creating  opportunities  for  private  investors  and  helping 
Indonesia to cover some lost ground in the sector. Among covering such other things as 
maritime safety and security, harbormasters, and establishment of a sea and coast guard, the 
law provides for decentralization, allows for private sector participation, and eliminates the SOE 
monopoly with a transition period of 3 years. After the transition period, PELINDOs I–IV will 
transfer their assets to the Government and their only role will be as port operators. Port 
authorities  will  be  established  on  a  regional  basis  under  the  Directorate  General  of  Sea 
Transportation to act as regulators. 
 
29.  In response to the growing demand, the Government has identified 1,532 hectares of 
additional land for the Tanjung port that will allow expansion beyond the present 604 hectares. 
The Government is also planning to develop specialized ports in the next 5 years, catering to 
the coal and palm oil industries through the PPP route. The current pipeline of ports sector 
projects includes both greenfield and brownfield development. These projects include general 
ports, industrial ports, container ports, fishing ports, plus cruise ship and ferry terminals. Thirty-
seven projects in the pipeline are either in the project planning or in the procurement stage of 
the project development cycle. They offer a total business opportunity of about $3.0 billion. This 
opportunity will become tangible, however, only if sector reforms are extended to their logical 
conclusions. 
 
F.  Water Sector 
 
30.  The water sector in Indonesia is a challenged sector, as access to water and quality of 
water and sanitation services are among the lowest in East Asia. Water’s service coverage ratio 
is barely 35% in urban areas and less than 10% in rural areas. The National Action Plans on 
Clean Water and on Sanitation issued by the MPW in 2004 aim to achieve close to 62% access 
to piped water by 2015 as an average for rural and urban areas. In addition, the National 
Development Planning Agency estimates that by 2015 the need for piped drinking water will be 
an additional 130,000 liters per second. The service delivery and management functions in the 
sector are decentralized, and urban water supply and management are the responsibility of 
approximately  315  regional  government  water  enterprises  or  regional  waterworks.  These 
regional structures are SOEs known as PDAMs. PDAMs report to the MPW; are owned by 
regional governments; and have generally been responsible for policy making, regulation, and 
project implementation. 
 
31.  The challenges in the sector emerge from the Government’s inability to fund investments 
for achieving the targets mentioned above. Investment of some $4.6 billion is required between 
2004 and 2015, from which the Government has budgeted around $650 million for the near term 
(up to 2009). It is well recognized, however, that the Government’s budget alone will be not be

Appendix 2  43
sufficient to cover these investment needs in the long run. That is especially true inasmuch as 
the investment requirements are huge and public funding in the sector has decreased since the 
financial crisis of the late 1990s. In this scenario, the need for tapping alternative channels of 
financing becomes even more significant, thus signaling the need for private sector participation. 
In  this  context,  private  sector  investment  will  require  many  sector  enablers.  A  ministerial 
regulation of 2006 provides for cost recovery and a reduction in consumer categories, but full 
cost recovery is not yet assured. While only a few water utilities operate at full cost recovery 
levels, PDAMs often pay unaffordable dividends to local governments and are compelled to 
maintain artificially low tariff levels. PDAMs suffer from high technical and commercial losses, 
they are little motivated to spend on maintenance activities, and water quality suffers as a result. 
 
32.  Private sector participation in the sector has been held to a minimum by the existing 
tariff-setting mechanism, uncertain regulatory framework, and PDAMs’ resistance to private 
operators that is primarily due to a lack of understanding about PPP at the local government 
level. About 70% of the PDAMs are in unhealthy condition due to low tariffs, mismanagement, 
and high debt levels. While a few PDAMs have had their debts restructured, with the help of 
technical assistance from Cipta Karya, it is imperative for the balance PDAMs (about 29) to also 
have  financial  statements  so  that  the  2006 exercise  of  mapping  306  PDAMs’  managerial, 
technical and financial performance could be extended to the remaining PDAMs as well. Both 
capacity  addition  and  resource  management  are  issues  needing  immediate  attention.  The 
sector has received only about $50 million of the investments needed between 2004 and 2015. 
That investment has primarily been into rural community schemes using central government or 
foreign  grant  financing.  A  few  water  supply  projects  are  emerging  that  have  a  combined 
investment  value  of  approximately  $600  million.  That  is  only  about  15%  of  the  required 
investment and leaves a visible investment gap of nearly $4 billion in the sector. It is thus 
evident that water and sanitation comprise a neglected sector among all infrastructure segments 
and continue to pose a developmental challenge. 
 
G.  Airport 
 
33.  The airport sector is an important one in Indonesia from the national policy perspective 
of regional cooperation and balanced regional development. The aviation sector was opened up 
to private operators in 1999, and the Indonesian aviation industry has witnessed rapid growth in 
passenger traffic. While domestic passenger traffic increased by about 250% from some 10 
million passengers in 1989 to 35 million passengers in 2006, international traffic grew by about 
100% in the same period from about 2.5 million passengers to 5 million. While the private sector 
was able to react quickly to market liberalization, the public sector components of civil aviation 
have been much slower in providing the additional capacity necessary.  
 
34.  The aviation was approved by the Indonesian Parliament in January 2009. Two of the 
major issues in the bill are (i) the provision of air traffic services by the Government as the single 
provider of those services, and (ii) the operation of airports by the private sector. The rapid 
growth of the aviation sector will be the major growth driver for any future development of 
airports as well as of supporting and embedded services. Passenger traffic reached 30.5 million 
in 2006 at Jakarta’s Soekarno-Hatta airport and is expected to touch 58 million by 2015. That 
will stretch the existing airport facilities as well as connectivity to the city. The Government is 
planning to build another terminal at the airport to meet the expected increased demand, as well 
as a connecting railway to Jakarta city to release traffic from the existing toll road. 
 
35.  The Government is likely to emulate its port sector model in airports, thus posing a 
considerable challenge for the existing SOEs to accept a new paradigm. As the aviation bill is

44  Appendix 2 
under  consideration,  it  is  expected  that  the  Government  will  provide  a  national  regulatory 
framework for airport operations that will allow a level playing field for airport operators to 
compete in terms of safety, operations, and efficiency. In addition, the industry is recently 
witnessing a trend where regional governments (such as Riau and West Java) are considering 
to build their own airports. This will put existing players in a dilemma whether to invest by 
themselves or enter into partnerships with regional governments. Currently, 17 projects are 
lined up in the sector with a proposed investment outlay of about $3.2 billion. Of these, the 
Government is currently focusing on projects involving the Medan Airport, airport in Makassar, 
and New Lombok Airport. 
H.  Railways Sector 
36.  While the road sector accounts for the majority share of domestic freight and interurban 
passenger land transport in Indonesia, the railways’ share dismally accounts for less than 1% of 
the country’s freight traffic and less than 10% of total passenger traffic. Railway operations are 
limited to predominantly passenger services in Java and three separate networks in Sumatra 
that carry mainly cargo such as coal and cement. The railways sector focus for the purposes of 
IIFF initially should be as a linkage sector to such natural resources as coal reserves and not as 
a transport sector that moves passengers and cargo. The private sector has shown increased 
interest in railway projects (and particularly for coal transport) as a result of the new law that 
allows  private  companies  to  build  railway  infrastructure  and  operate  rolling  stock.  PLN  is 
currently  building  10,000  MW  of  power  plants  under  the  crash  program  (expected  to  be 
completed by 2010–2011) that have backward linkages with coal mines located in Kalimantan. 
The business-to-business railway network project connecting these mines with ports represents 
an investment of about $3 billion and should generate interest from private players. The IIFF 
focus on the railways sector should be on structuring viable projects that provide linkage to 
natural resources. 
I.  Natural Gas Sector 
37.  Indonesia has the largest proven natural gas reserves in the Asia and Pacific region. As 
of  December  2006,  proven  gas  reserves  in  Indonesia  were  92.9  trillion  cubic  feet  and 
represented 8.2% of the world’s total proven reserves. While Java’s industrial area is the major 
consumer  of  that  natural  gas,  the  majority  of  the  reserves  are  located  in  Sumatra  and 
Kalimantan. That highlights the need for a transmission network across these islands. It has 
been estimated that Indonesia’s gas reserves have not been explored to their potential primarily 
because this transmission infrastructure is lacking. 
38.  Responsibility for the sector lies with the Directorate General of Oil & Gas in the Ministry 
of Energy and Mineral Resources. The sector has two regulators: Indonesian Oil and Gas 
Upstream Regulatory Body (under Government Regulation No. 42 of 2002) and Indonesian Oil 
and Gas Upstream Regulatory Body (under Government Regulation No. 67 of 2002), the latter 
regulating  distribution  of  fuel  oil  and  transportation  of  natural  gas  through  pipelines.  PT 
Perusahaan Gas Negara (PGN) is the dominant SOE, having about 86% of the market share in 
the gas transmission and 93% of the market share in the distribution business, respectively. In 
order to meet the domestic gas demand, and especially from the power and industrial sectors in 
eastern and western Java and northern Sumatra, the Government has facilitated the process of 
setting  up  pipeline  and  non-pipeline  infrastructure.  There  is  a  large  gap  between  existing 
demand and available supply in these regions.

Appendix 2  45
39.  The gas sector was opened up to competition in 2001 by the Oil & Gas Law No. 22/2001, 
thus ending the monopoly nature of the business. That law firmly states that “the downstream 
activity in the natural gas distribution and transmission businesses should not be obtained 
through any privilege (monopoly), but through a bid mechanism.” The law was based on two 
main principles: (i) the unbundling principle (i.e., that a company operating a business in the 
upstream sector is prohibited from running a downstream business, and vice versa), and (ii) the 
principle of open access to and joint payment for pipeline network facilities. The restrictions 
imposed by the unbundling principle have resulted in upstream companies’ not being able to set 
up  their  own  transmission  infrastructures,  thereby  making  them  wholly  reliant  on  PGN’s 
transmission and distribution infrastructure. As the major industry player, PGN has consistently 
invested in augmenting the pipeline network. PGN lined up total investment of about $268 
million  in  2008,  spread  across  transmission,  distribution,  and  liquefied  natural  gas  (LNG) 
infrastructure.  
40.  The  PNG  South  Sumatra  West  Java  transmission  infrastructure  project  will  be 
completed by October 2008. The West Java distribution expansion will be fully operational in 
2009. The LNG receiving terminal will be completed by 2014. Integrated coal-based methane 
development with transmission pipelines is another important project that is currently underway. 
Apart from these projects, there are about eight projects under various stages of development 
and with expected investment needs of about $2.1 billion. Most of PGN’s projects are in an 
advanced stage. 
J.  Waterways Sector 
41.  Ferry terminal and ferry operations are critical to the connectivity of the islands and act 
as cost-effective gateways for the movement of passengers, vehicles, and cargo across the 
archipelago. These operations comprise an important ingredient to industrial and economic 
development. Nearly 40 million passengers and 10 million vehicles are transported each year 
on Indonesia’s 85 ferry routes. More than 75% of the traffic is concentrated on just three routes: 
Java–Sumatra, Surabaya–Madura, and Java–Bali. The Java–Sumatra route carries the largest 
volume of vehicles of any ferry route in Indonesia. 
 
42.  Despite the significance of waterways in the country, the level of connectivity between 
islands remains a matter of concern for the transport sector. Forecasts anticipate that by 2009 
the total Indonesian ferry system will be carrying almost 48 million passengers, 14 million 
vehicles, and over 20 million tons of cargo. On the Java–Sumatra ferry lines alone, the traffic is 
predicted to increase from 8.9 million passengers and 2.6 million vehicles in 2004 to about 10 
million passengers and 3.5 million vehicles by 2010, then further to 12.6 million passengers and 
5.6 million vehicles by 2020. 
 
43.  Anticipating saturation of the existing Merak–Bakauheni route based upon consultants’ 
various  sector  studies,  the  Government  identified  the  Margagiri–Ketapang  Ferry  Terminal 
Project as a model project. It is one of the 10 model projects that could be implemented through 
the PPP route and that were short listed at the Indonesia Infrastructure Summit in 2005. On 
behalf of the Government, the Ministry of State-Owned Enterprises and MOT are cooperating in 
support of the PPP format for developing this project. Technical responsibility for the project lies 
with the Directorate General of Land Transport under MOT, while the Directorate General and 
the sub-directorate for rivers, lakes, and ferries are in charge of policy formulation.  
 
44.  The estimated investment for the Margagiri–Ketapang Ferry Terminal project is $97 
million. The consultancy work for this project has been segregated into two phases. Phase 1

46  Appendix 2 
preparing the prefeasibility study as described in the Presidential Decree 67. Phase 2 would 
bring in private developers if there is general consensus on taking the project forward based on 
the findings of phase 1. 
K.  Subnational Infrastructure Projects 
45.  The different tiers of government in Indonesia include the central (national), provincial 
(subnational),  and  district  or  municipality  (also  subnational)  levels.  After  decentralization, 
Indonesia’s  subnational  governments  have  become  among  the  fiscally  strongest  in  the 
developing world. This is partly because subnational governments have recently benefited from 
record-high reserves. In mid-2006, these reserves reached Rp95 trillion, or 3.1% of GDP. This 
is  in  sharp  contrast  to  the  pre-decentralization  period,  when  surpluses  were  nonexistent. 
Between 2001 and 2005, provinces, districts, and municipalities accumulated more than Rp35 
trillion in reserves—about 18% of (2005) subnational expenditure and 1.4% of (2005) GDP. 
Reserves began to soar in the first half of 2006. Subnational governments are mainly funded by 
intergovernmental fiscal transfers. In spite of record high reserves at the local level, most 
subnational  governments  have  been  unable  to  utilize  these  burgeoning  reserves  for 
developmental purposes. The funds are invested into risk-free government securities instead of 
being used for developmental purposes at the local level. It is therefore reasonable to conclude 
that fund availability at the local level is not a matter of concern. Rather, what is of concern is 
the management and use of these funds.  
 
46.  IIFF can make a big impact in this area. It can become actively involved in project 
preparation and development at a subnational level to prepare bankable projects. IIFF can 
begin  by  identifying  a  few  pilot  projects  at  the  subnational  level  and  working  closely  with 
subnational government on those projects. Ideal would be to work on multiple pilots, rather than 
on a single pilot, as the risk of failure for a single pilot project would be rather high. 
 
L.  Conclusions 
 
47.  As described, various sectors are at different stages of evolution. IIFF will need to 
articulate a unique strategy for every sector. Whereas some sectors will be potential candidates 
for funding, others will have to be targeted for project preparation and associated fee-based 
services. In adopting strategies for prominent sectors, the key point for gaining private sector 
finance—whether through public-private partnerships, asset sale, or leasing contracts—is to 
secure a predictable set of tariffs as per a tendered contract (so that it is not open to political 
interference). The gas transportation and pipelines sector (with PGN) is where this has been 
best achieved to date. In that sector, it is now possible to securely raise funds both domestically 
and from abroad. 
 
48.  The toll road sector has a history of private sector finance, albeit under the privilege-
based direct appointment model. There is now a commercially expert management team in 
place at Jasa Marga, however, and it has successfully conducted an initial public offering and a 
bond  issuance.  Jasa  Marga  should  now  be  capable  of  packaging  old  and  new  toll  road 
proposals in a manner that gains private sector finance. These should be coherently packaged 
while bringing economies of scale and scope and so that the regulator (BPJT) can benchmark 
performance.  This  process  also  requires  that  the  regulatory  body  be  given  greater 
independence  from  ministerial  interference.  To  date,  the  institutional  investors  and  key 
investment banks with a history of investing in toll roads have resisted Indonesian toll roads, 
despite many attempts in Jakarta to attract their interest. One theme the IIFF could address is 
the packaging of toll roads with upgradation plans for public roads, bridges, plus port and rail

Appendix 2  47
access in order to attract finance within a well-defined transport plan. Surabaya and Jakarta 
outer ring road are active possibilities in the “packaging” department. 
 
49.  While  the  planning  process  (ideally  involving  a  transport  master  plan)  is  a  key  to 
sustainable investments in projects such as toll roads where the externalities are substantial, in 
fact there is a paucity of well-developed integrated plans in most of Indonesia. A role for IIFF will 
be to ensure that transport investments are both consistent with sound sector analysis (ideally 
with  an  acknowledged  plan)  and  structured  in  such  a  fashion  as  to  facilitate  bankability, 
regulation, and thus funding for both the long and short term.  
 
50.  The water and sewerage sector is most critical in terms of the Government’s policy 
strategy. Water treatment and distribution are capable to attract private sector finance, but 
under  less  risky  management  contracts  than  many  of  those  to  date.  This  has  been 
demonstrated in Tangerang. Full concession contracts have been a problem, as evidenced by 
all the political interference and consequent insecurity in Jakarta’s water concessions. 
 
51.  Airports, including Jakarta’s Soekarno-Hatta but also many regional airports (e.r., Medan, 
Surabaya,  and  Denpasar),  could  be  made  highly  attractive  to  private  investment  through 
advisory roles and then arrangements for financing by IIFF. It needs to be appreciated that 
airports raise both competition issues (for landing slots) and commercial opportunities (e.g., 
retailing). There are also linkage issues, such as how other transport systems interface with the 
airports. This suggests that IIFF, as well as general planning and policy processes, will be key 
to facilitating transport investment by private sector consortia in the early years. 
 
52.  Telecommunications are by their nature what economists call excludable goods. They 
are characterized by the fact that the customer contract makes private sector finance relatively 
easy to attract, regardless of whether or not the structure is appropriate. Indonesia has recently 
demonstrated through the successful tender of the 3G frequency band that it is capable of 
implementing sound private sector investment and competition in telecommunications. IIFF is 
thus less critical to this sector, but that should not mean its exclusion. As exemplified in the 
current case of Temasek investment in more than one telecommunications entity, there are key 
policy issues of interest in Indonesian telecommunications and thus a role for the independent 
policy and advisory expertise of a well-structured IIFF cannot be undermined.

1.  The Indonesian financial system has remained resilient in recent years, supported by 
monetary stability and improved domestic economic conditions. Potential vulnerabilities may 
stem from a volatile external environment due to the likes of excessive global liquidity and short-
term capital inflows, oil price volatility, and other global imbalances. Internal structural issues 
within Indonesia’s financial system include a strong dependency on bank financing and a high 
concentration  on  consumer  financing.  Bank  Indonesia  has  undertaken  certain  initiatives  to 
reduce vulnerabilities to these risks. These include improving bank risk management practices 
and bank supervisory processes, strengthening financial infrastructures (financial safety nets), 
and improving the effectiveness of macro surveillance.

appraisal,  and  finance  group  can  create  separate  teams  with  specializations  in  different

5.  Fee-based products will be offered through advisory vertical. It will include policy and

6.  The chart also depicts the responsibility of the chief financial officer (CFO) in treasury,
