B.  Staffing Strategy 
 
7.  It is recognized that a critical success factor for the IIFF is the quality of its human 
resources and leadership. In this context, the president director will play a crucial role. He or she 
will have a mandate to manage the operations of a start-up entity and quickly demonstrate 
success as measured by financial closure of infrastructure projects in the country. He or she will 
manage a team of professionals with diverse backgrounds in the likes of infrastructure, banking, 
finance, and economics. Reflecting these facts, he or she is expected to be experienced in 
project as well as people management and should have a demonstrated track record of the 
same. His or her role is envisaged to be an all-encompassing one as a visionary, coach, 
motivator, and strategist for the business and the team.  
 
8.  The president director will be a person with a strong vision for IIFF and have extensive 
cross-sectoral and cross-functional experience in infrastructure in order to provide suitable 
policy and business direction to the IIFF team. It will be essential for the president director to be 
a passionate thinker who can lead IIFF’s efforts to anchor the intellectual capital related to 
public-private partnership, as envisaged in IIFF’s vision statement. The president director will 
need  to  be  assisted  by  a  core  team  of  professionals  who  will  also  play  a  crucial  role  in 
establishing IIFF’s credibility. The engagement of a president director will be a condition for the 
Asian Development Bank’s equity disbursement. 
 
9.  To ensure availability of the required mix of skills, IIFF will follow a multi-pronged staffing 
strategy covering: 
(i)  Direct appointment. The core staff of IIFF, such as the president director, head 
of operations and advisory, CFO, and head of risk management, will need to be 
recruited as permanent employees. These positions are expected to be lateral 
movements of senior professionals from the market, such as investment bankers, 
infrastructure  specialists,  finance  specialists,  and  private  sector  participation 
specialists. While an Indonesian national can be preferred for the position of 
president director, the other positions can be sourced from overseas, too, in 
recognition of the fact that local talent for the roles envisaged may be scarce.  
(ii)  Management  contracts  and/or  retainer  consultants.  Several  functions 
envisaged for IIFF (e.g., project appraisal and finance) lack both quality and rigor 
in Indonesia today. One reason cited for this gap is a shortage of skills. Hence, 
these positions could be globally sourced as management contracts. Moreover, 
the strategic project advisory function could work on similar principles, wherein

52  Appendix 4 
various  aspects  of  infrastructure  projects  would  be  outsourced  to  technically 
adept  and  professional  entities  and  individuals  in  the  areas  of  project 
conceptualization, feasibility, structuring, etc. It needs to be ensured that such 
management contracts require the selected firm to develop and embed relevant 
skills and processes within the IIFF organization. 
(iii)  Secondments,  exchange  programs,  and  deputations.  As  a  new  entity  in 
Indonesia, IIFF will face some uncertainty in its initial years until its business 
model gets established. Creating a large base of permanent in-house staff at all 
levels may thus be neither prudent nor necessary. Moreover, the process of 
developing  a  team  to  address  IIFF’s  requirements  could  benefit  from  the 
experiences  of  similar  institutions  abroad,  such  as  the  Infrastructure 
Development Financing Company Limited (IDFC) in India and DBSA in South 
Africa.  In  addition,  training  and  capacity  building  at  the  early  stages  of  the 
institution’s establishment would be foundation stones for its success. These 
objectives  will  be  met  through  secondments  and  deputations  to  the  extent 
possible. Secondments of core staff to similar institutions elsewhere could be 
made  with  the  objective  of  obtaining  hands-on  training  from  experienced 
personnel around the world. Exchange programs are likely to be even more 
beneficial. While a resource from IIFF gets trained at, say, IDFC, an employee of 
IDFC could step in at IIFF and perform an identified role for the exchange period. 
Such programs, lasting from a few months to a couple of years, tend to provide a 
steep learning curve and could prove to be mutually beneficial to participating 
institutions while leading to professional satisfaction for all concerned. This option 
will  also  be  explored  especially  with  some  employees  of  the  international 
financial institutions that are shareholders in IIFF.

Appendix 5  53
RISK MANAGEMENT AT THE INDONESIAN INFRASTRUCTURE FINANCING FACILITY 
COMPANY1 
 
A.  Importance  of  Risk  Management  to  the  Indonesian  Infrastructure  Financing 
Facility 
 
1.  Risk management will be a critical function for the Indonesian Infrastructure Financing 
Facility Company (IIFF), given that the risks associated with infrastructure funding are high. That 
is especially true when, as in the case of Indonesia, the demand-side sectors are going through 
a transition in terms of the policy and regulatory frameworks. While on the one hand risks 
emanating from the asset portfolio will be high, on the other IIFF will need to provide competitive 
funding to infrastructure projects. This implies that IIFF will need to maintain a low cost of funds 
by achieving a high credit rating (i.e., national scale rupiah debt rating). Not only is the high 
credit  rating  necessary  to  achieve  a  low  cost  of  funding,  it  is  also  consistent  with  IIFF’s 
envisaged positioning in the Indonesian financial markets. It is in the context of this high credit 
rating objective that the risk management assumes central importance. Recognizing this, it had 
been proposed that a detailed assessment of the risks, and leading to recommendations as to 
the risk management approach and strategy to be adopted by IIFF, be carried out prior to IIFF’s 
incorporation.2 
  
2.  Accordingly, the broad approach to risk management to be adopted by IIFF is outlined 
below. 
 
B.  Indonesian Infrastructure Financing Facility Company’s Broad Approach to Risk 
Management 
 
3.  IIFF will treat risk management as an essential element of its organizational culture, and 
the function will thus be reflected in every key area of IIFF’s operations: (i) structure; (ii) people; 
(iii) product mix; (iv) policies, goals, and standards; as well as (v) systems, processes, and 
procedures.

areas.

Appendix 6  55
CORPORATE GOVERNANCE AT THE INDONESIAN INFRASTRUCTURE FINANCING 
FACILITY COMPANY 
 
1.  The  Indonesian  Infrastructure  Financing  Facility  Company  (IIFF)  will  be  required  to 
establish and adopt the best corporate governance practices in line with its positioning wherein 
it needs to be seen as a credible institution in the eyes of all stakeholders. Certain aspects of 
corporate governance for IIFF are prescribed by corporate law (UUPT, 1995) and law related to 
capital  markets.  For  example,  the  Articles  of  Association  forming  part  of  the  deed  of 
incorporation will cover certain aspects of governance, especially with regard to the rights of 
shareholders. The three main organs for effecting corporate governance—the general meeting 
of shareholders, board of commissioners (BOC), and board of directors (BOD)—and certain 
minimum criteria regarding such matters as frequency and composition of meetings are also 
specified  by  law.  In  addition,  there  are  aspects  of  corporate  governance  addressed  in 
regulations prescribed by Bapepam-LK, the regulator and supervisor of capital markets and 
listing requirements of the Indonesia Stock Exchange that would become applicable for IIFF. 
(The listing requirements become strictly relevant only at the time of a future initial public 
offering, but these will be adopted from the outset to the extent possible.) In addition, IIFF will by 
and large adopt standard codes of good corporate governance such as those prepared by the 
National Committee on Governance and the Forum for Corporate Governance in Indonesia 
even though these are not mandatory in nature. 
 
2.  Accordingly, the focus is to go beyond the standard codes and to outline certain specific 
elements of corporate governance that are important in the context of IIFF’s operations and that 
should be adopted by the company. These elements of corporate governance are presented 
using  the  following  framework  for  classifying  corporate  governance  benchmarks  and  best 
practices.

3.  The specific elements of corporate governance to be adopted by IIFF are as follow: 
 
A.  Category  of  Corporate  Governance  Elements:  Management-Shareholder; 
Structure Related  
 
(i)  Composition of the BOC. In light of the mix of government and nongovernment 
shareholding in IIFF and its proposed positioning that emphasizes skills and 
relationships, IIFF’s BOC will play a vital role in ensuring that IIFF develops in the 
desired manner and in order to realize its objectives. An effective BOC should 
not be too large but still should ensure that the main shareholders (including the 
Asian Development Bank) and critical skills are represented on the BOC. The

56  Appendix 6 
presence of some reputable independent commissioners is also important to 
ensure objectivity in dealing with conflicts between shareholders and to lend 
additional credibility to IIFF.   
(ii)   Nomination  and  compensation  committee.  A  critical determinant  of  IIFF’s 
success will be the caliber of the president director and other senior director-level 
employees. This is an aspect that requires the involvement of the BOC, and, in 
the interest of streamlining this involvement, a nomination and compensation 
committee of the BOC will be formed at an early date after incorporating IIFF. 
The  nomination  and  compensation  committee  would  be  responsible  for 
identifying and assessing suitable candidates for the president director and other 
key positions, as well as for matters related to compensation. The compensation 
schemes for employees, directors, and commissioners should have components 
that are linked to IIFF’s medium- and long-term performance in order to align the 
interests of employees, BOD members, and BOC members more closely with 
those of shareholders. 
(iii)  Credit committee. IIFF’s credibility in the initial years will be established only if it 
can pursue and close suitable opportunities. An erroneous funding decision can 
have an adverse impact on IIFF’s credibility and affect its operations. To guard 
against this, IIFF proposes to set up a credit committee of the BOC to take the 
final decisions on all funding proposals involving funding above a set minimum 
amount of IIFF’s exposure, say Rp200 billion.1 While all papers relating to all 
funding proposals will be placed before the BOC, it would be unrealistic and 
inefficient to engage the entire BOC in such discussions for all funding proposals 
irrespective of the size of IIFF’s exposure. Accordingly, the formation of a credit 
committee of the BOC is essential to ensure that all large exposures taken by 
IIFF have the benefit of being examined by the subcommittee of the BOC. In 
order to ensure that the credit committee functions in the desired manner, a 
comprehensive policy for the composition and functioning of the credit committee 
will be formulated. For proposed exposures that are even larger, say over Rp400 
billion,2 the entire BOC will be required to examine the proposal and take a joint 
decision.  
(iv)  Audit committee. A subcommittee of the BOC to look after audit, chaired by an 
independent commissioner and comprising all the independent commissioners 
such  that  the  independent  commissioners  represent  the  majority,  will  be 
established. The chairman of the audit committee will be a chartered accountant 
with long experience in finance and audit-related functions. The audit committee 
will have frequent contact with the external auditors and also spend considerable 
time with the internal audit team that oversees internal controls. The internal 
audit team will jointly report to the president director and the audit committee. 
(v)  Risk management unit. An independent risk management unit reporting directly 
to the president director and to the audit committee will be set up with the 
objective of establishing policies for the management of IIFF’s market, credit, 
portfolio, and operational risks and of monitoring their implementation. The risk 
management unit will operate independently from the other operational units 
within IIFF, and employees in the unit will have no incentives linked to the volume 
of lending achieved by IIFF in a given period.

shareholders’ agreement. Significant resources will be allotted to the task of

appraisal,  and  credit  sanction;  (g)  proceeds  of  any  issue  of  equity;  and  (h) 
relationships with and activities among employees and the wider community. 
 
4.  IIFF  shall  maintain  a  highly  informative  website  that  includes  important  legal  and 
disclosure documents, including a full range of debt offering memoranda, shareholder rights, etc.

Appendix 7  59 
ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIAL MANAGEMENT SYSTEM OF THE INDONESIAN 
INFRASTRUCTURE FINANCING FACILITY  COMPANY 
 
A.  Guiding Principles 
 
1.  The Indonesian Infrastructure Financing Facility Company (IIFF) will review its overall 
risk management process in the context of the proposed Asian Development Bank (ADB) loan. 
It will be required to formulate a corporate policy for environmental and social management and 
establish an environmental and social management system (ESMS)1. Guiding principles would 
be the following: 
(i)  IIFF’s  compliance  with  applicable  environmental,  social  safeguard,  and  land 
acquisition and resettlement laws and policies of ADB and the Government of 
Indonesia. 
(ii)  Integration of environmental and social safeguard compliance of investments into 
IIFF’s due diligence process and independent credit risk review. 
(iii)  Establishment of environmental and social safeguards, including a resettlement, 
screening,  classification,  and  assessment  system,  to  identify  and  monitor 
adverse environmental and social impacts associated with its business activities, 
including  wherever  deemed  necessary  for  projects  supported  in  importing 
countries. 
(iv)  Identification of appropriate mitigation and compensation measures to minimize 
adverse impacts in line with international standards. 
(v)  Public disclosure of environmental and social impact information in the review 
process. 
(vi)  Promoting  customer  compliance  with  applicable  environmental  and  social 
safeguards,  including  resettlement  laws  and  standards  in  Indonesia,  through 
appropriate documentation of environmental and social impact studies, approvals 
by authorities, and site visits as appropriate. 
(vii)  Where applicable, prompt interaction with the client in the case of breaching 
relevant laws and standards in order to prepare a corrective action plan. 
(viii)  Appropriate staffing of IIFF’s risk management unit and operational departments, 
as well as annual action plans to develop and operate the ESMS. 
 
B.  Environmental and Social Management System 
 
2.  IIFF will be required to establish and adopt an ESMS to be approved by its board 
comprising an ESMS policy, ESMS procedures, and a board and ESMS capacity building plan. 
In due course, IIFF will submit a detailed description of its ESMS.  
 
3.  Environmental and Social Management System Policy. As part of the process of 
establishing an ESMS, IIFF will prepare and adopt an environmental and social safeguard policy 
statement to the effect that (i) it will actively encourage and require its customers to observe all 
applicable environmental and social requirements; and (ii) if the relevant business activities of a 
customer contravene applicable environmental and social safeguard requirements, it will take 
action  to  understand  the  reasons  for  noncompliance  and  shall  discuss  with  the  customer 
corrective actions acceptable to the relevant authorities.  
 
4.  Environmental and Social Management System Procedure. Before providing any 
loans funded under the loan to a customer, IIFF will verify that the proposed business activity is 
                                                 
1  A more detailed draft is included in Supplementary Appendix 2

60  Appendix 7 
not on ADB’s list of prohibited investments. IIFF will undertake an initial assessment of whether 
the relevant business activities of the customer, in the reasonable opinion of IIFF, have a 
potential to have an adverse environmental or social impact or may involve land acquisition, 
entail involuntary resettlement, or affect indigenous people. 
 
5.  In the event that IIFF determines that the relevant business activities of a customer may 
have a potential significant adverse environmental or social impact or may involve involuntary 
resettlement or affect indigenous people, it will, prior to providing any financial assistance: 
(i)  Consult with and assist in providing advisory or other services to such client. 
(ii)  Undertake an assessment as part of the lending or investment due diligence 
process  in  order  to  satisfy  itself  that  the  relevant  business  activities  of  the 
customer comply with all applicable environmental and social requirements. 
(iii)  Where the relevant business activities of the customer constitute a category A or 
category B project,2 undertake an environmental assessment that addresses the 
following key environmental and social issues: 
(a)  environmental and social conditions of the investment; 
(b)  requirements  under  relevant  laws,  regulations,  and  applicable 
international agreements, including but not limited to laws and regulations 
governing land acquisition, compensation, resettlement, and indigenous 
people; 
(c)  sustainable development and use of renewable natural resources; 
(d)  protection of human health, cultural properties, and biodiversity, including 
endangered species and sensitive ecosystems; 
(e)  socioeconomic impact; 
(f)  land acquisition and land use; 
(g)  impact on indigenous peoples and communities;  
(h)  cumulative  impact  of  existing,  proposed,  and  anticipated  future 
investments;  
(i)  participation of affected parties in the design and review of mitigation and 
rehabilitation measures;  
(j)  consideration  of  environmentally,  socially,  and  economically  feasible 
alternatives; 
(k)  efficient production, delivery, and use of energy; and 
(l)  pollution prevention and waste minimization, pollution controls (regarding 
liquid  effluents  and  air  emissions),  and  solid  and  chemical  waste 
management.  
(iv)  Where  greenfield  development  or  significant  expansion  is  involved  that  may 
involve involuntary resettlement. 
 
6.  In the event that greenfield development or significant expansion is involved, IIFF’s 
credit committee will determine whether land acquisition and involuntary resettlement may be 
involved. If it is not able to reasonably satisfy itself that the relevant business activities of the 
customer comply with all applicable national environmental and social requirements and that 
involuntary resettlements are not involved, IIFF will do one of the following: 
(i)  Decline to provide funding to such customer. 
(ii)  Offer funding and associated services subject to the condition that the customer 
shall implement an agreed corrective action plan within a specified period of time.  
                                                 
2  A project is classified as category B if its potential environmental and social impacts are less adverse than those of 
category A projects. Typically, impacts are site-specific, few if any of them are irreversible, and mitigation measures 
are readily available.

Appendix 7  61 
(iii)  In a case that possible involuntary resettlement cannot be avoided, IIFF will 
require  the  prospective  borrower  to  prepare  and  submit  a  resettlement  plan 
prepared in accordance with this policy as outlined under section. This plan will 
need to satisfy IIFF that resettlement is minimized and that affected people will 
receive appropriate compensation. During implementation of the investment, IIFF 
will (a) monitor implementation of the resettlement plan, and (b) distribute status 
reports as committed under such plan. 
 
7.  Environmental  and  Social  Management  System  Capacity.  The  ESMS  will  be 
established through the following: 
(i)  Integration  of  environmental  and  social  safeguard  aspects  in  the  appraisal, 
approval, and monitoring processes. 
(ii)  Adequate staffing of IIFF’s risk management unit and operational groups. 
(iii)  Designating  the  Credit  Committee  as  the  decision-making  and  reviewing 
authority for the ESMS. 
 
8.  Reporting. IIFF will prepare an annual report, in respect of loans extended under the 
facility, summarizing the following: 
(i)  Environmental  and  social  impacts  of  investments  supported  by  the  facility, 
including progress for each investment subject to a resettlement plan. 
(ii)  Compliance with core labor standards and measures for prevention of HIV/AIDS 
as part of health and safety. 
(iii)  Any areas of noncompliance or other issues arising from the environmental and 
social safeguards, including resettlement, and indicate prospective investments 
where policies relating to these areas may be triggered. 
(iv)  Periodic reviews of the ESMS, striving for continuous improvement. 
 
C.  Staffing and Capacity Building 
 
9.  An  appropriate  number  of  IIFF  staff  members  will  be  assigned  to  operate  the 
environmental management system. 
 
10.  IIFF will send at least one of its senior representatives to ADB-sponsored or approved 
environmental and social safeguard training.

SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY 
  
Country and Project Title: Republic of Indonesia: Indonesian Infrastructure Financing Facility Company Project 
 
South East Asia Department

Modality:  Division:

I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
Infrastructure development and economic growth are strongly linked. Greater provision of infrastructure and related services 
has a particularly beneficial impact on the poor by, for instance, improving access to markets and areas with greater economic 
and employment opportunities. For the poor, in particular, improved water supply and sanitation, rural electrification, and 
better community and subdistrict infrastructure can have tremendous beneficial impacts. Moreover, investments in human 
capital and in infrastructure interact, thus increasing the returns to each investment. Investment in infrastructure services can 
contribute to sustainable growth by (i) reducing transaction costs and facilitating trade flows within and across borders; (ii) 
enabling  economic  agents—individuals,  firms,  and  governments—to  respond  to  new  types  of  demand  in  different 
geographies; (iii) lowering input costs in the production of almost all goods and services; (iv) opening new opportunities for 
entrepreneurs or making existing businesses more profitable; and (v) creating employment  
 
Indonesia’s poor investment climate and major deficiencies in infrastructure provision have been identified as key constraints 
to growth. Infrastructure progress has virtually been at a standstill since the 1997 Asian financial crisis. Due to lack of 
adequate investment for maintenance, the quality of existing infrastructure has worsened. In particular, the deterioration of 
water supply and sanitation infrastructure and of transport networks (roads, railways, and sea transport) has led to a lower 
quality of life for the poor. For instance, a large majority of the population (an estimated 210 million) living outside of urban 
areas does not have access to sewerage systems.  
 
The constraints that affect growth and impede poverty reduction are characterized by 
(i)  poor service coverage outside of Java, in general and in all infrastructure sectors (Where some services are 
available, the quality is low, disjointed, and unreliable; 
(ii)  regional  disparities  in  the  availability  of  public  sector  resources  and  weaknesses  in  legal  and  institutional 
frameworks (which curtail investment); and 
(iii)  failure to meet public service obligations by many state-owned enterprises, and lack of a consistent approach 
across the sectors in this regard. 
 
The absence of local infrastructure is most critically felt by the poor, whose livelihoods are acutely affected by inadequate 
infrastructure. Shocks to the national economy, such as the rationing of electricity, are particularly evident to large numbers of 
people dependent on employment in small enterprises in the informal sector. While indirect benefits are harder for poor 
people to perceive, it is clear that the development and maintenance of national infrastructure is essential if Indonesia is to 
secure the potential gains from globalization. Improving availability at the local level alone is unlikely to transform the 
economy, and developmental benefits will not be fully realized unless simultaneous improvements at the local and national 
levels are introduced and managed. 
 
The Indonesian Infrastructure Financing Facility Company Project (IIFF) complements other ongoing sectoral programs, such 
as the Infrastructure Reform Sector Development Program (IRSDP)a, to adopt a comprehensive approach for dealing with all 
of these issues over the medium term. Given the complexity of reforms, the IRSDP adopts a program cluster framework to 
support infrastructure development in a phased manner. The establishment of the Indonesian Infrastructure Financing Facility 
is an outcome of the policies agreed upon under IRSDP. The benefits to society arising out of improved and more equitable 
access to infrastructure and the strong linkages between economic growth and investment in infrastructure are  well 
established on the basis of global experience. The primary objective of these programs is to improve the investment climate, 
and thereby to boost economic growth and reduce poverty 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General Intervention 
1.  Key Issues  
The proposed intervention in IIFF seeks to support the Government of Indonesia’s objective of increasing the flow of private 
investment into infrastructure projects to a level that is six to seven times the current average level and overall to have a net 
beneficial impact on poverty reduction. Besides addressing the immediate quality of life concerns (through, for instance, 
leveraging improved provision of water supply and sanitation services), the IIFF will enhance access and employment 
opportunities for the poor. In parallel, the Government is implementing the Rural Infrastructure Strengthening Program (also

Appendix 9  65 
supported by Asian Development Bank [ADB] through the Rural Infrastructure Support Project, approved in December 2005), 
which gives special attention to infrastructure needs in poorer and disadvantaged regions of Indonesia.  
II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 
The IIFF supports implementation of the Government’s programs on poverty reduction. The Government has identified 
infrastructure development as a key element of national policy, and it has initiated reform measures and progressive 
legislation to facilitate infrastructure development. In particular, the establishment of IIFF has close linkages with the 
Government’s medium-term development plan with its clear poverty reduction targets of halving poverty from 16.6% in 2004 
to 8.2% in 2009.   
 
Some noteworthy features of the linkages between IIFF and the National Poverty Reduction Strategy include the following:  
(i)  The IIFF  will focus on enhancing private sector participation in the National Poverty Reduction Strategy’s 
implementation through broad-ranging measures. It will facilitate the flow of private funding into infrastructure 
projects in Indonesia by making long-term funding available for such projects and establishing credible frameworks 
to attract investment flows from various categories of private sector investors. 
(ii)  Measures  for  mobilizing  public  and  private  sector  resources  for  immediate-  and  long-term  infrastructure 
development will have significant effects on poverty reduction. 
(iii)  The focus on risk-sharing to encourage private sector participation will help meet the demand for infrastructure 
needed to provide basic services and attract productive investments to generate employment.  
B.  Consultation and Participation 
1.  Provide a summary of the consultation and participation process during the project preparation. 
 
2.  What level of consultation and participation (C&P) is envisaged during the project implementation and monitoring?  
  Information sharing          Consultation         Collaborative decision making       Empowerment 
 
3.  Was a C&P plan prepared?   Yes      No  
IIFF is anchored on ADB’s IRSDP as well as on the Government’s comprehensive infrastructure policy package. In 
formulating this package, the Government undertook several rounds of consultations with a broad range of stakeholders. ADB 
participated  in  these  consultations.  The  establishment  of  IIFF  has  also  involved  a  consultative  process  involving  all 
stakeholders. ADB and other development partners supporting the establishment of IIFF have been involved in this process. 
C.   Gender and Development 
1.    Key Issues. Women will benefit from the subproject through improved access to various infrastructure services and more 
affordable pricing of the same. This is also true for women entrepreneurs who have suffered due to the lack of high-quality 
infrastructure, such as regular power supply for production units and roads for market access without the need to walk 
through difficult terrain. Further, regular water supply and adequate drainage improves working conditions for women 
employees. Moreover, high-quality infrastructure will assist women and other vulnerable groups through better quality health 
care and education. Finally, women will benefit from subprojects that conform to required environmental standards.
